We have had similar arrangements elsewhere (Paris, Rome), which worked well because the internal doors could be left open when needed, but at The James this is not possible because the internal doors cannot be held open. Tying the door handle to the cupboard handle with a sock in order to hold it open was hardly the sort of solution I expected to have to use in a “luxury boutique hotel” (although it worked quite effectively).Taking into consideration the cost per night, the rooms are very small – the standard queen even qualifies as minute – although we got used to it eventually. There is a paucity of cupboard space, no carpets, and the bathrooms are functional if not overly large or aesthetic. On the whole, rather a spartan décor - but the beds were definitely comfortable and the rooms are well maintained and spotlessly clean. Quite a bit of noise from the corridor at night. A welcome plus is free WIFI throughout the hotel, a pleasant change from the daily rates charged in most hotels. Service was courteous, efficient and responsive. All our requests were handled promptly. The Concierge was helpful and friendly, and a special thanks must go to Eric the Doorman, who acted swiftly to avert disaster and very quickly arranged alternative transport when our car service failed to arrive to take us to a show (Book of Mormon, no less).Public facilities are rather meager, the lobby lounge is a bit nondescript, but the gym is well equipped and located on the 17th floor giving a great view. The lounge/bar on the top floor was packed every time we ventured up there, it seems like a popular evening venue. Unfortunately the weather was still rather chilly so we did not get to enjoy the outdoor facilities, although the “plunge pool” on the roof is precisely what it says it is.Location is good, somewhat on the edge of Soho’s shopping district, but still within easy walking distance, as is Greenwich Village nearby. Proximity to the entrance to Holland Tunnel causes quite severe traffic congestion in the area during peak hours. There are a lot of excellent restaurants in the vicinity, and the concierge was very helpful in that regard. The David Burke Kitchen which is in the basement of the hotel (a “partner” venture), offers meals to house guests including breakfast. It was not really to my personal liking, but the cuisine was certainly of good quality.In conclusion, what the James lacks in space and comfort, it makes up in excellent service. However, the overall experience somehow lacks the “wow” factor that I believe one is entitled to expect from a facility which markets itself as a luxury hotel.

Stayed there over the Christmas and NYE in a Corner Room. The room was a decent size for New York and we did have a great view as it was a Corner Room. We didn't have any problems with sounds form the bar (I suspect as it is Winter and hardly anyone is up there).My husband and I love boutique hotels and this hotel was divine. There is lots of artwork all over the hotel which we loved. The staff uniforms are very different and all staff were very helpful too. Location was very good with 2 nearby subway stations and easily walkable around SoHo. Loved their toiletries too.The rooftop bar was good unfortunately was too cold for us to properly enjoy.We did have a meal downstairs, I wouldn't recommend it. Much better places to eat at in New York, but was convenient for us.

We just got back from a 3 day weekend getaway at The James. The Hotel was very clean, well kept and the staff extremely helpful and friendly. The self serve coffee in the Lobby in the morning was wonderful,as was the free Wifi..Morgan at the concierge desk was very knowledgeable and recommended great restaurants nearby, taking care of the reservations which were confirmed by email to us. This was very appreciated. We did not try the Hotel restaurant but did go to Jimmie's for a drink on 2 occasions...we found it a bit young for our age (53 & 57), so we did not linger very long.A special thank you to Erik the doorman, who made the Taxi hunt a bit more bearable for us who were new at this "law of the jungle" and were taught to be more assertive.Overall a very nice and clean Hotel which we would not hesitate to recommend in the Soho area.

I stayed for 5 nights with my family and enjoyed the location. We were able to walk to many great restaurants and shops. The rooms are small, even for New York standards, but nicely decorated and the bed was very comfortable. The bathroom had a great shower and intelligent nutrients toiletries which I loved. The only setback is that you can hear a lot of the noise from the rooms next door. The doormen Eric and Michael were very sweet and helpful.

Friday night and the bar was packed with workers and tourists alike creating a good atmosphere. The drinks were spot on; gin and tonic had a generous splash of gin. Tip: Go to waitress at side of bar to avoid the wait for the barman. Best part was the view at Sunset on deck around pool making it an excellent but brief experience.

I needed a new place to stay in New York City this week. A friend recommended the James. And I could not be happier they did! The bed was hands down more comfortable than my bed. The area around the hotel was awesome. I could have walked around for hours. The staff was beyond friendly! I felt so welcomed! I loved my stay! Thank you! Thank you! Thank you! And thank you, Kris, for the recommendation.

Rooms were small but that's expected in NYC, it's not 5 star but has some nice touches that make it boutique. Nice Shower room, with environmentally friendly toiletries, nice robes, and slippers, hand made truffles each night, 3 times filtered water on the bedside, great views, we were on 11th floor. Very helpful front desk staff, passionate about the 'other' side of New York. We got some great tips on where to eat/shop. Jimmy's bar was very cool, with great cocktails and tapas. Very close to Canal Street Subway, just a short ride away from Times Square, Central Park, Fifth Avenue, and with the boutiques, cafes and restaurants of Soho and TriBeCa, on the doorstep. Downside was housekeeping, our room was really dusty, but when we mentioned it, they sent someone to sort it out, and offered us a credit for the restaurant, which they very generously transferred to Jimmy's to counter our rather large Cocktails bill. Coffee and a pastry available in the morning from the reception lounge, and I believe wine was served in the evening, but we were out and about enjoying the lovely areas close to the hotel, and having a great time.

I should be writing a glowing review of this lovely hotel. I am lying in a comfortable bed, looking out huge windows facing was on its 9th floor. What could possibly be wrong?Little things. But lots and lots of them. Pillows - ordered pillows from the menu in the room. Got the wrong pillows delivered. asked for the write pillows. got more of the wrong pillows. showed the book to the man. told me that they were out of them. got a call saying "we can purchase them tomorrow if you want us to". I said "why are you asking me? am I supposed to be guilty about the fact that you have to purchase what you are offering as part of the James experience?" Came back to room the next afternoon. Still no pillows...A list: lots of room noise from above (maybe the lack of carpet to sound damp?) low water pressure in shower. you wait forever for an elevator because there are only 2! Coffee and pastries does not mean a selection of pastries, but a pile of a single mediocre pastry. My key did not allow me to take the elevator to the roof at 5:30PM, as promised. Housekeeping weird - didn't put away iron and ironing board. Why would I want it left out? Duvet cover had chocolate stains (I hope thats what they were...). Used dental floss on counter not thrown away - did they think I intended to reuse it? (yes, I should have thrown it away myself...) No greeting from concierge on arrival. No doorman ever. AC blows directly on bed. TV picture too dark, and remote does not allow you to adjust it. No channel guide for cable TV - only channel list. I've been searching for that perfect NYC boutique-ish hotel in the Soho area. I've stayed at the Mondrian Soho a half dozen times and thought I would try some where else - the Mondrian's standards are slipping a bit. I want to be delighted for less than $500 a night. Is that too much to ask? At The James, yes, apparently it is.

We just got back from a weekend at The James where we celebrated the one year anniversary of our engagement and had an absolutely stellar weekend. I didn't want to go home! The hotel was a very convenient location for us, as most of our plans were in the SoHo, TriBeCa area of NYC. It was a little over a mile walk to the 911 Memorial and Battery Park with tons of great restaurants, shops and bars nearby.We were greeted with warm welcomes and the front desk checked our bags until our room was ready. The room was modern, clean and about the size of what you'd expect for a NYC hotel room. Loved the bathroom shower!The hotel is located near the entrance of the Holland Tunnel so you'll hear lots of horn honking, but you're going to hear horns no matter where you go in city.Kate, the bartender on the main floor was a sweetheart. She was super friendly and gave us several great suggestions for places to go. Thank you to Kate for her "Big Three" - they were big hits! Also, the guy with the long hair who works at the front desk is also really nice and helpful with a sense of humor. The housekeepers were also very friendly and accommodating.Saturday night we went up to Jimmy for a drink, where the vibe was a little more "cool" - too cool for us. We're old and not that hip, so we had a glass of wine, enjoyed the spectacular views and hit the sack.Would definitely recommend the hotel and would love to stay here again.

This was our second trip to NYC. We thought we'd experience the culture of Soho. The James Hotel was beautifully contemporary. Each floor/room was decorated by a local artist. Spacious and clean, with comfort in mind. We were impressed with the service overall. It was quiet, offered amazing views and was in an excellent location. Staying at The Pearl the day before, we thought The James was refreshing and a great experience. Walking distance to Canal street. Only a few blocks from the Financial District. Great views from the roof top terrace and great little pubs in the area. It's a true standout and in every sense of the word a boutique hotel. We are planning a trip to Chicago and will be staying at The James!

I stayed at the James for a week with my sister as a big birthday treat! Whilst we did enjoy the stay and the facilities and location are excellent, the attitude of the staff was a real let down to an otherwise excellent experience. The concierge who is bizarrely located downstairs away from all the guests has to communicate with the sky lobby via a radio so that if you want an answer to something even basic like the price of the spa treatments you either have to ask someone in the sky lobby to radio down while you wait as they won't know the answer or you physically have to go down in the lift yourself and ask. The bartender in the treehouse bar was rude, on our first night we were tired and hungry from our long flight and we waited over 20 minutes to be served as he was watching ice hockey on a massive tv. We also found that the staff in the sky lobby were unable to help with most things such as general info about soho and directions to local places which you would expect. The hotel is cool and the staff are pleasant but don't expect any actual assistance, use google in the lobby!

I really like the artwork in The James Hotel. I'm really happy with my room. I'm extremely disappointed in the service... and I still have four more nights here. I don't know if I can make it.The rooms are nice. I'm on a high floor with nice windows. The rooms are well-appointed and average size for Manhattan. I'd be happy here except:1) They forgot my wake-up call - I'm a business traveler and I rely on wake-up calls to help me get going. This is inexcusable.2) I returned last night to a seemingly clean room, except the cleaning staff (I hope) left their disgusting, dirty and still wet, latex gloves sitting on my desk. That's just gross.3) I ordered room service (which I do often when I'm traveling.) The food was mediocre at best - which I've come to expect - except the pasta dish I ordered wasn't what the menu reflected. It was missing ingredients. When asked, the staff told me I had an old menu. I requested a new menu and they said there wasn't one.This hotel is too nice and too high-priced to have such terrible service. I won't stay here again and I certainly wish I hadn't booked 5 nights. What a mistake...

Michael is excellent he took me the place he goes for his repairs he took me all the way to repair shop said they will take care of it and they did and he went to pick it up for me I didn't have to worry or waist time he dropped it in my room it was the best care I felt like a queen. And the hotel itself is amazing and a delight ad very unique Loby is sky Loby all the hotel rooms have best view and plus u get complimentary vine at only happy hr times coffe tea snacks every hr if u have needs like water ,ice run out of something they deliver it very quickly like u never run out And they green hotel so they bottle of 1 litter filtered in glass bottle every day I love this hotel

I stayed at the James for three nights over Presidents' Day weekend. I LOVE the location. Close to a ton of fun bars and restaurants and SHOPPING. Also close to public transport. Do not try to get here on a Friday night though as the traffic to the tunnel will be such that you will have to get out of your taxi and WALK for blocks and blocks with your suitcase.I also loved the design of the rooms. Everything was very comfortable and well thought-out. There was even an extension cord for my all devices!!!! And free wifi all the time, although at times it was slow to non-existent. (Note, there is a shade you can control from the bathroom that will separate the sleeping area from the bathroom.) Also LOVED the bath products tremendously.But here are the things that happened while I was there, some controllable, some not:Down to one guest elevator. Whoever designed the hotel elevator system was not an expert in expressing guests to their rooms. The two elevators were slow enough as it was. Imagine what happened when the service elevator went out and the staff had to use the guest elevators. I started timing the elevator on my floor and would often wait 7 minutes for the lift, although one would arrive repeatedly during this time with the guy with the cart with all the empty glass water bottles, jingling. This was a bit of a mess. (And he was not the world's most happiest person.)The fight in the hotel room above me. So bad that at 2:30 am that I had to call the front desk. Not the hotel's fault at all. But the fight went on for ages and ages. (I really wish she had taken her high heels off.) I should have called sooner. If I've ever felt bystander apathy before, it was now. Did everyone really wait so long to call the front desk??Overbooking via Expedia. One evening, every time I showed up in the lobby, someone was crying. The hotel had been overbooked by Expedia. (Not their fault, I am hoping.) But what was the hotel's fault was the quality and quantity of their communication with the affected guests. As I was enjoying the free wine and cheese, I watched a few different groups of guests just sit there for ages, just waiting and waiting for information about their rebooking. Very binary transactions. I don't know...I just feel like the hotel could have been more caring and provided these guests with more updates. The craziest thing that happened was one afternoon, as I was waiting for the elevator (!!! see above), mindlessly thumbing my iPhone, a cleaning person approached me and told me their name and asked me to make sure I mentioned them on TripAdvisor. :(Oh lastly...had lunch at David Burke the day I checked out and the service was pretty flaky. I was meeting a friend there and we both told them that and they sat us separately, which was pretty funny GIVEN THERE WAS ONLY ONE OTHER TABLE SEATED. Also one server, while kind, had a noticeable body odor problem. So...a little dysfunctional, this stay at The James. But I'd still go back.

The hotel my company usually books was unavailable - lucky for me, since that landed me at The James! It had been awhile since my last trip to NYC so I asked for a higher-level floor and as such, was upgraded to a deluxe king. The view to the river was fantastic. The room itself was very clean, mod and functional and, most important to me, very quiet. As with most hotel rooms in the city, it was on the small side and would have been cramped with more than one person. My only other complaint is the time it took to locate all the light switches (and there are many). I was very tired the first night so it was a bit aggravating to have to hunt them down. But not enough to take away from the amazing service I received, whether from the front desk, the concierge, the doorman, or room service. When the server brought dinner to my room and I commented that I had come in too late to take advantage of the wine served in the lobby, he returned in a flash with a complimentary bottle! So thoughtful. The bathroom was surprisingly spacious and well-designed. There is a motorized curtain (with some very cool artwork imposed on it) that separates the glass wall between bed and bath, unlike some hotel rooms I've seen that don't give you that option. In addition to room service, I had a late breakfast at David Burke Kitchen downstairs - excellent food and service.While this was a quick business trip, I hope to return to The James again when I have the luxury of more time. Thank you for making this part of my journey so comfortable!

I've stayed at the James at least six times in the past year and it's always great. Rooms are comfy, location ideal in soho and service is always top-notch. For gym lovers... It's a nice but small gym

My husband and I had one night to spend in the city and, luckily, chose the James. From the moment we entered we knew we had chosen wisely and well. The reception desk was warm and welcoming. The bell staff was helpful and accommodating. The room service waitstaff could not have been more kind. All in all, a perfect hotel experience. We will be choosing The James for another visit!

I liked The James a lot. The rooms are small, but that's to be expected in NYC. The hotel itself is very nice. They usually have a bit of food or wine out in the lobby. The rooftop bar is fun, and the restaurant was good. The location is excellent. I would stay here again. The only reason I don't give it top ratings is that the housekeeping was a bit irregular, and there were a few other small issues. Nothing serious, though.

Beautiful designBut very disappointed in the functuallity in the room. The drapes should be on a motor. The hand held shower is weird, no dresser for clothes, no body lotion, no room for clothes in the closet, no room for luggage, nice booze bar. No room for toiletries in the bathroom.Nice view though.For some reason we were not allowed in the dining room."..........Chris and Eric are extremely nice!

The James is my new favorite hotel in my home city. The staff is incomparable--they took care of every need, even fixing a mistake I had made with the reservation. The hotel is immaculate and luxurious--but having stayed at many beautiful hotels, I can say that the service at The James is at the top. Everyone is kind and thoughtful. We plan on staying here for our "nights away" every opportunity we can.

We spent a weekend in NY. The location of The James is great. Very convenient for a shopping trip. The hotel is chic and stylish. Beautiful design of the lobby. The room was small but with a great view and a very comfortable bed. Stylish bathroom with big shower. Our room was not super clean, also the maintenance of the furniture in our room could have been better. Even though complementary breakfast was offered, one day at 11am there was nothing left. We did enjoy our stay in the hotel but there are some little flaws.

If you can afford to, try it. The James Hotel is a top, top notch hotel. It doesn't surpass the Firmdales or the Soho Houses as destinations when it comes to visiting and chilling out at during the day/night time. But to stay, it certainly does! It's all about experiencing the atmosphere, visuals, quality of surroundings and service that makes this hotel so impressive. Congrats to them. We left saying a) we'll be back & b) 'wow, they really nailed it'!

This hotel is fantastic, from the valet staff to the rooftop bar - we had a fantastic time! The area is great for wandering around and soaking up the atmosphere. Best bit about the hotel was to sit out in the sunshine having a few cocktails on the rooftop bar during the day before a quick dip in the pool and then back up at night to see the city's lights. Great atmosphere and the staff could not do enough to help. The rooms are spacious we had a corner room which had amazing views on 2 sides of the building. The bathroom is not huge, no bath but excellent shower. The bed was bigger than average and very comfy. Valet parking was worth the money - the staff took great care of our car.

...but after that, tho I think the hotel wants to be first rate, it falls short, mainly by design.Dont get me wrong, it is a nice hotel, chic, clean, bright, but the way some things are laid out is just not comfortable. The most glaring example to me is the lobby on the 2nd(?) floor, there is very little in way of guidence for one to know that unless you are already on the elevator (which by the way is also hard to figure out as there is more than one when you walk in and little to tell you you are on the wrong elevator) The first impression of the hotel fo me was not welcoming, just a bare cold lobby with invisible direction. The guy at the door should have provided some assitance but alas, we hauled our bags onto the elevateor with other people only to find it didnt take us were we wanted to go. And hey, I'm GOOD with direction. This was just too minimalist were it needn't be. I get the cool factor that some hotels don't even put the name on the front, but geez, where do I check in after a long trip?In the early afternoon we called ahead to see if our room would be ready, they said not til after 3. Fine. So at 4, after finally finding the (tiny) checkin desk, we are told the room is still not ready, given a card for a free drink downstairs (which elevator is that again?) and we enjoy a wonderful cocktail. One drink and an hour later the room is still not ready so we enjoy another fine drink. An hour and $52 later the room is still not ready so we leave the bags at the tiny desk and head out into wonderful Soho. A call an hour later later has the info our room is 'almost' ready and probably will be by the time we get back. Geez i need a shower. At 7 we head to the hotel and finally get a room and 30mins to shower and dress for a dinner. The view from our room is vast but not that intersting looking out over the concrete park at Ave. of the Americas and Grand in the winter, but at night head to the rooftop bar for a great view of the lower city. The pool in summer must be awesome up there.

My husband and I stayed here after enduring 12 days without power after Hurricane Sandy. The rooms are small but well designed. I loved the bathroom...huge shower! David Burke Kitchen is a must-visit for brunch....incredibly delicious!

This is our second stay at The James. Our first stay was so wonderful that we brought our teenage daughters this time. We've sent several friends to stay here. We live in the NY area, and are both native New Yorkers. We came for winter break to be tourists in our own city. The James is located at the bottom of Soho just above Canal St., but you would never know that when you enter the hotel in Grand St. It feels rather private. The second floor lobby adds to that feeling. Also, since there is no direct route to the rooms from the street level, it adds some security. The elevator requires you use your key to enter a floor number. The girls had their own room and I wasn't worried about their safety. If you are a downtown person you can't beat the location. Soho to the northeast, TriBeCa due south, Chinatown southeast. For those who want to travel further afield, two subways within a couple of blocks, as well as busses and cabs.The Rooms: All rooms have nice views. Request a room that faces south so you can see the Freedom Tower (almost finished). Yes, the rooms are small, but this is NYC folks! The rooms are modern and nicely equipped. Beautiful dark wood cabinetry and floors. Cool lighting. The beds are amazingly comfortable! So are the pillows. Then there is the bathroom. The shower has a really luxurious rainfall head (I have one at home, but it's not this fabulous). Some rooms have heated tile floors. The bathroom has a glass wall with a shade, that has an artistic image, for privacy. Our girls found that fun. Shampoo, conditioner, lotion...lovely. The Staff: Very friendly and welcoming. Michael, Michael, Michael! Michael from In-room Dining, shines! Yes, we love him that much. He started our days with a smile. Since it was vacation and it was cold, we decided to treat ourselves to room service breakfast in the mornings. Seeing Michael first thing in the morning was a great way to start the day. He's friendly, sweet, knowledgable, helpful...a great guy! I'm going to miss when we leave today. Camille from housekeeping is another keeper. My husband had a gout attack and when I mentioned it to her she shortly came to our room with a pile of towels, plastic bags and buckets full of ice. The front desk staff were also lovely. I believe that all we had to do was ask and whatever we wanted would appear graciously.The Food: David Burke, no complaints, though the restaurant is not as polished as David Burke Townhouse. The service was nice but the food was not quite there. Don't get me wrong, it was good, just not as fabulous as it should have been.Can't wait to come back.

The James is a chic hotel with modern rooms; we had a corner room with walls of windows facing east and south. All hotel staff were friendly and made us feel welcome. The hotel has a fantastic outdoor roof deck pool which also doubles as one of the great bars downtown. The David Burke Kitchen restaurant was a great spot for brunch - the pretzel crab cake was delicious.

My husband and I recently stayed for 1 night at the James...we live within driving distance of NYC and often come into the city for an overnight. Tribeca and SoHo are our preferred locations so booked the James because of this and so many "outstanding" reviews on Trip Advisor. While I have no complaints, the hotel was just OK...really nothing special. There is essentially no lobby...the check-in desk feels like curbside check-in at an airport (though certainly a very friendly staff). We arrived in our corner king room to find an article of clothing (left behind by a previous guest, we later found out) sitting on the table upon entering the room. Not the first thing you want to see in your hotel room. We paid additional for an upgraded room, a corner king "studio," which was only slightly larger than the king bed. The room was well appointed but, again, nothing special. We visited the rooftop bar after dinner and enjoyed a drink. The bar feels very separate from the hotel itself so it doesn't really feel like it is part of the property; we did not dine in the restaurant on the ground floor but, again, because it is not really "connected" to the hotel lobby it is more of a stand alone. The receptionist touted the morning coffee and pastries at check-in so I returned to the lobby the following morning. And found a very paltry counter with a coffee thermos and small tray with 2 straggler pastries on it; you would certainly find a more impressive spread at a Courtyard Marriott for $89 per night. If you are traveling to New York you can do much, much better than The James. With the ever expanding number of downtown, hipster hotels there are numerous offerings in the area with so much more, particularly for the price.

We had very high expectations after having an outstanding experience at the Chicago location. Both have amazing, hospitable staff who really make you feel welcome from the moment you arrive. Unfortunately the room in NYC was a bit disappointing. It has a cold feeling to it, very small, not great layout. It isn't a bad place if you've got money to burn but for the price it was a splurge for us and did not live up to what we expected (and hoped) after Chicago. The location, however, is outstanding, close to all the shopping you could hope for as well as restaurants, cafes , and bars that really feel local and not touristy at all.

This is a brilliant art driven boutique hotel with David Burke Kitchen on the ground floor. The rooms are comfortable with terrific rainfall showers. The staff from the doorman to the concierge are friendly, attentive, attractive and impecably attired in fantastic custom designed outfits. The housekeeping staff and cheerful and hard working ladies. I plan to stay here multiple times in the future.Alfred Anderson, Director of Gift Planning, University at Buffalo.
user_name:
Alfred A
Buffalo, New York, United States

review_body: Treated myself to a trip to NYC for my 40th birthday and had a great time staying at The James. Very stylish, comfy good size room (I had a King) and great location in SoHo, within a few minutes walking distance of the Subway. Staff were very friendly, helpful and professional and presented me with a lovely birthday cake on the day, which was a nice touch. I ate in the David Burke restaurant and while the food was good, the service was a bit slow - got my cocktail with my starter and didn't get the white wine I ordered with my starter but wasn't charged for it. I would happily stay again and recommend to anyone who wants a decent value (not cheap, but worth it) stylish hotel in New York with great access to the whole city.

Booked The James as we had read positive reviews online and we weren't disappointed. Prior to arrival I had received welcoming emails and had asked the concierge to recommend some restaurants, which they booked on our behalf (Public on Elizabeth St for Saturday night-amazing food and great vibe). They also arranged for us to have simultaneous massages in our room(as there is no spa) early evening, which were fantastic and perfect after a day in the city. We arrived on the Thursday (had dinner at Freemans-1 Freemans Alley with friends-again couldn't fault the food and great buzzy place) with lots of 'historical storm on its way' talk from the locals with recommendations not to go out after 8pm on the Friday evening. We did however have a few drinks in Jimmy's rooftop bar and then ventured across the road to Cafe Noir which is a cosy tapas bar with delicious food and stumbling distance home! Hotel location was ideal, close to Broadway with mainstream shops but lots of boutiques on side streets. Saturday the city was covered in snow and looked stunning. Having left 2 children at home we wanted the hotel to be trendy, but not too cool, in a great location and this fitted the bill. Service was pretty good, room (corner suite on 9th floor) was a good size with a superb shower. Read a review about bed bugs on arrival from another website and this concerned me greatly, but didn't see or feel any evidence of this! Breakfast was ok but toast cold and chewy most mornings! Used the gym on 17th floor which was small but adequate.

I really wanted to give this hotel a 5 star review but they fell slightly short at check in hence the 4 star rating. I stayed at The James with my husband in Sept/Oct 2012. This was a very special visit to New York as we were there to get married. I had informed the hotel of this beforehand as I needed some recommendations on florists in the area. We arrived at 2pm which is the official check in time and were told that our Corner King Studio room was not ready because they wanted to make some extra special touches to the room for us due to the fact that we were in NYC to get married. They suggested that we wait in the rooftop bar until our room was ready. An hour later we went back to reception and were told again that they were still trying to make the room extra special. We were told that the front desk would call us as soon as the room was ready so we decided to explore Soho a little. Another hour later we still hadn't heard anything so we called the front desk only to be told that the room still wasn't ready. Eventually 10 mins later we got the call and went back to the front desk to collect our keys and officially check in. By this time we were pretty tired but everyone who we dealt with so polite and we felt that their intentions were good so we didn't feel the need to make a fuss. When we got to the room everything was fine but we didn't see why we were made to wait over 2 hours for our room to be ready as there were no 'special touches' evident. Whilst we would never expect anything complimentary just because we were there to get married, it was annoying that they had used the excuse that the room was not ready because they were doing something extra for us when in fact it just simply wasn't cleaned/serviced until over 2 hours after the official check in time. They should have said that the room wasn't ready rather than using our wedding as an excuse. Positives-The Staff. Everyone we encountered was extremely polite and helpful. The concierge team did a great job with recommending an amazing florist, organising a dinner in a nearby Soho restaurant for friends and family the day before the wedding and with arranging transport on the actual wedding day. A special mention to Morgan who answered all emails prior to our stay very promotly.-Corner King Studio room had amazing views of downtown Manhattan. It was very spacious and worth the additional rate.-Comfy beds-Powerful and large shower with organic toiletries supplied-Complimentary filtered water was a nice touch as were the cookies and chocolates at turn down.-Wide choice of breakfast included in the room rate on an in room dining basis only. -Room service was always prompt-Overall feel of the place and contemporary decor made the hotel a very relaxing environment.-David Burke Kitchen. We dined there in the evening on one occasion and the food was delicious.-Jimmys bar. Yes the service was a little arrogant but with the view and the delicious cocktails, who cares? -Complimentary car service/bikes for hire. We didn't use this but thought it was a nice touch.-Complimentary coffee and pastries in the morning and wine and cheese in the evening.-Lots of outdoor space-Location. Close to the subway and the fantastic restaurants and shops in Soho.Negatives-The lifts got quite busy in the evenings due to non-residents using the same lifts to get to Jimmys Bar. Overall we had a truly memorable stay at The James and we hope to return for our 1 year wedding anniversary this year.

This is a great chic little hotel in Soho. Have stayed several times while on business. Clean comfortable , but small rooms. Nice lobby lounge with wine for happy hour. Friendly staff. would recommend

I was here for four days last week with my husband while he did some business in the area. During the day I was left on my own and the staff was great help. The doormen were so nice when I had a question with what subway to use. I ordered room service 2x for breakfast and Erica remembered my order exactly. She even knew I liked my milk steamed!!! The lobby was great with complimentary cheese and wine in the evenings. I will for sure be returning!

The James is a newly built chic boutique hotel in trendy Soho. We had a fabulous week in chilly January for our honeymoon. Everything about the hotel is great, from the moment we arrived at the trendy lobby, the helpful front desk person, the stylish, but functional room and the glass facade bathroom with electric privacy curtain (generally not used by us). We enjoyed the morning complimentary coffee and pasties in the lobby.The only downside i found the free Wifi clunky, as i needed to re log in frequently on 2 iPhones and an iPad, as the system drops out after a short period of non use.

I stayed here for 2 nights last week for a mix of business and pleasure and had a wonderful experience. The hotel itself is great--love the modern, sleek decor, and the huge windows in the rooms. Unlike the other reviewer, I found the bed very comfortable. The location is, obviously, superb. The real standout was the staff--everyone was so friendly, from the doormen, to the concierge (Morgan was especially great), to the front desk staff, to the housecleaning staff. Loved David Burke Kitchen, too. In short, stay here. You will not be sorry.

Stayed at the James a night over the last weekend. The Jimmy, ofcourse we loved. Great views, good cocktails and friendly staff. Room was super small, and the bed was very uncomfortable.. We ordered room service, and the food was very average to the point its below even a dinner food in new york.. Quite disappointing given its a gourmet chef.. I would not stay here, but will visit Jimmy,
user_name:
Nycnls
New York City, New York

review_body: I travel regularly to NY for work. Last year, I stayed at The James and had a wonderful experience. The service, the staff, the amenities, the room, everything and everyone was remarkable and thoughtful. However, I got it in my head that I wanted to try new hotels on each visit, so on my next few trips, I sampled some other boutique hotels.This week, I was stranded in NYC for an extra night due to a flight delay. I had our assistant at work contact the James immediately. If I couldn't be home, I wanted to stay in this warm, cozy, friendly place. I felt so defeated by my day as I checked in (having gone to the airport only to be told I could not make it home and a long sad taxi ride back into NYC). Upon check in, the manager thoughtfully offered me a glass of wine and sincere empathy. My luggage was brought immediately to my gorgeous king corner suite with an amazing view. I decided to take myself pity shopping and let me tell you, every single designer or shop you could want is minutes from the James. Upon my return, I ordered room service and enjoyed high end 'comfort food' from David Burke Kitchen. It was as nice a substitute for home as I could possibly have imagined.It is the little things- both in the room and regarding the staff- that will make this my go to hotel from here on out. The filtered water by the bed, the Intelligent Nutrients products in the shower, the welcoming lounge floor with wine and cheese and great seating, all the way down to the thoughtful personal note attached to my emailed invoice from the desk staff. I will be back in a few weeks and I am looking forward to an amazing 'home base'.
user_location: Santa Rosa Beach, Florida, United States
user_name:
Megan T
Santa Rosa Beach, Florida, United States

review_body: My wife and I stayed at The James Hotel for our 10-days in New York. The James was just fabulous and I could not recommend it highly enough. We had a ‘standard’ room on the west side on the 14 floor with a wonderful view. The room was clean, neat and very well-designed for its compact size. The hotel is relatively new and while we raised the average age, we always felt welcome at all times. All the hotel staff were friendly and very helpful. The staff were quick to brave the cold to hail cabs and on a number of occasions confirmed restaurant bookings and other related matters.The hotel is about 100 metres from a Metro train station (for the Red 1 line), while access to stations for another Metro line are also within an easy walking distance. While the hotel’s address is on Grand Street it is effectively on the corner of 6th Avenue and Grand Street, which makes securing cabs a relatively painless exercise.The hotel’s restaurant (David Burke) was excellent and the need for a reservation at night was proof of its popularity. We also ate close by on a number of occasions (the Lucky Strike Restaurant and Cipriani Downtown). Balthazar (excellent) for brunch is also within an easy walking distance. The complementary wine and cheese at night was a nice touch, as was the coffee and muffins in the morning before you headed out for the day.

As someone who dabbles in design, this property stands out among the others. It is clever and modern, with unusual angular architecture. The property monopolizes on fantastic views and has unique artistic touches. The keyboard wall in the entry floor is brilliant, the "molecule" design chandeliers in the lobby are stunning and each floor features different artists work. In the room, the design is equally impressive, especially the glass wall dividing the bathroom and living area, which has a retractable shade for privacy. The bed is uber-comfy and the mini bar is well-equipped. Having a little space in the mini-fridge is helpful too. Bottles of water are provided, too. The happy hour in the lobby is lively, with wine and cheese provided and comfy seating areas. Morning coffee with pastries are a perk as well. The gym has good equipment and views to motivate your workout. Michelina in housekeeping was particularly responsive. This is a great spot for a getaway - the decks look amazing for summer trips - mine was a winter escape so I'll have to return!

My girlfriend and I splashed out on this hotel on our return to New York, and we were NOT disappointed.Everything from the individual staff members, the service of the front desk and concierge, the nibbles, fruit, free wine and cheese at night, were all just perfect. Free wifi, a great gym and great location make this place a very funky MUST in New York...Don't look any further :)

My wife and I went on a 24 hr. staycation here for her birthday and had a wonderful time. It felt like we were a long way from the Upper West Side suburbs. We stayed in an apartment suite on a high floor. The space and the city views were spectacular! The bathroom was huge with a relaxing tub and a very spacious shower. Everything was spotless, and the service was friendly. The fitness room was also on a high floor with great views and natural light. We had dinner at David Burke Kitchen which didin't live up to expectations. The next day we took advantage of the hotel's location and enjoyed Soho on foot. One minor drawback to the floor to ceiling windows is that morning light seeps in from the top of the large curtains, so if you are light sensitive, you may be awakened earlier than you would like. Overall a wonderful experience and a great place for a downtown experience.

Made a quick trip to the city for some holiday shopping, but some of my gifts (sweaters for my dad, uncle and husband) didn't come back with me. I was stoop-id and checked bags with hotel bellman at 2pm checkout but when I got home, my gifts were gone -- apparently sifted out from a larger bag I had carefully re-packed. I should have known better, but up to that moment, the staff was helpful and ultra-hip. And, I even tipped the jerk!Otherwise, I appreciated the location and savvy staff for recommendations finding late-night food (well after the bar shut down) and local hot spots. But one BAD APPLE poisoned the James for me - won't go back because someone on the staff is a creep.

My wife and I stayed at the James SOHO this past weekend and it was incredible. From the moment we checked in we felt like VIPs. We were set up with dinner reservations by Morgan the concierge in Little Italy where the food was fantastic. She then recommended a restaurant for breakfast because of the food and possible celebrity sightings, and low and behold, we did see 2 celebrities there and the food was great. We were surprised with a nice plate of goodies when we got back from dinner which was very nice of Morgan to do for us, and made us feel like family. Kristina and Amy were super friendly in greeting us whenever they saw us and knew us by name as we walked around the hotel, which was really nice. All the staff were great, from the doormen to the cleaning staff.I would recommend this hotel to EVERYONE that wants to stay in NYC. If you want to feel loved, spoken to by name, and spoiled rotten, then this is the hotel for you.Thanks Morgan, Kristina, and Amy for a wonderful time!!!!

Stopped here for a drink and an appetizer on Saturday afternoon. I especially adored the glasses that they drinks were served in. The bar tender was friendly and the food was tasty (french fries and a cheese plate). This is an excellent spot in Soho!

I note that one reviewer stated this hotel was not as nice as The Crosby. That may be true but it is also way less expensive. One has to compare hotels at the same price point. I had many issues upon arrival and also with the state of the room....many of the features were not working and it had not been readied for guests properly. At first the hotel was slow to correct this. However when I contacted management they put everything in order very quickly. Judging by the other reviews on here I have to assume that my problems with things not working in the room was just an unfortunate fluke that can happen in hotels and as I stated it was ultimately handled well.Every single staff member I came into contact with was just lovely. With the exception of upon my arrival when there was no one at the door, no porters and reception did not seem to care everyone else really went out of their way to be friendly and helpful. I had a few meals in The David Burke Restaurant which was very very good. Room service was very good for breakfast with an insanely fresh and very nicely sized fruit plate. Room service dinner was hit or miss....great one day and then way way too salty by any standard the next. That's odd because I presume it comes from The David Burke Restaurant but maybe the foray into the salt mines was also a fluke.The coffee and scones in the lobby that as many reviewers have noted changes to water and fruit, then wine and cheese and finally cookies is more than a nice touch. It really creates a very nice atmosphere.I also really like that they give filtered water in bottles in the room. The bedding was terrific as was the bed. Nice mini bar. There was no price list in my room and I looked everywhere so I can't comment on cost but they had very good items. Judging by my bill I think the cost was probably in line with similar hotels in NYC. I am not a fan of furniture that elevates form over function. To this extent I did not feel that the round table and modern but not terribly comfortable chair in the room was a good substitute for a desk. However this was more than made up for by the fact that where they have the free food station in the lobby lounge they also have computers and a printer free of charge and comfy sofas and chairs with views through surrounding windows of the area. Essentially you get a biz center instead of a desk but you don't have to pay for it. They even offered me coffee one day when I was working there after coffee service and brought it to me free of charge.The area is terrific. Shops, restaurants and a subway right there. The rooms are small so be prepared. I had a corner king and the bathroom was big but that did take away from rest of the room. I have stayed at many many hotels in NYC. The James is right up there at the top of the hotels I would return to.

My boyfriend and I stayed at the James and were both very happy with our stay. We stayed in a King corner studio and the room was gorgeous. I love the decor, and the see through bathroom! (there is an electric blind that you can lower for privacy). The service was great: it was his birthday so upon checkin we had complimentary champagne and cake, and they also accommodated my request for a room on the highest floor available. They provide coffee and scones in the morning and wine and cheese in the evening. The views and the hotel are beautiful. It's close to the subway so it's very easy to get around the city. Staying in Soho is a great way to experience the city, but avoid a lot of other tourists. We'd love to come back on our next stay!

I like The James' location and the uncluttered, yet warm and sophisticated decor! I LOVE their committment to offer a wonderful blend of environmental conciousness with a luxury feel! That is hard to achieve. Everything is effortless and at your fingertips. The staff is genuine and caring. The James New York has become my favorite place to stay whenever in New York. Keep it up.

What distinguishes this hotel is the quality of the staff - which is exceptional. The location (edge of Soho) is good although the most immediate environs are not brilliant. The entrance is small and not too prepossessing but, once one takes the lift to the lobby, one can relax. The lobby is small but comfortable (complimentary coffee and scones from 0600 to 1100, water and fruit from 1100 to 1800, wine from 1800 to 2000, and cookies thereafter). The basic (i.e. Queen) rooms are adequate but the superior rooms (i.e. King) are good although clothes hanging space is limited. The bed is excellent and the bed linen very comfortable. The wifi is free (but tends to drop occasionally). Breakfast is served in the basement restaurant run by David Burke, and is rather disappointing (or, at least, was disappointing on the only occasion that I went there): there is little or no atmosphere at breakfast and the subterranean location does not help. My omelette was decidedly tired. (A short walk from the hotel will bring several places where breakfast is good: particularly Balthazar in Spring Street). The gym is good. I recommend this hotel despite the minor criticisms mentioned above - as I began, the staff are quite exceptional.

A great NYC choice for business or vacation. Upgraded to a corner king which is still small but terrific finishes (hardwood floors, heated tile, good lighting) and finally a room with a view in the city! Staff are shockingly friendly and helpful. The whole place feels like you're staying in someone's apartment (wine in the lobby, coffee and pastries, free wifi). Superb location for SoHo restaurants and subway access. A winner.

As frequent traveler with a life time of Marriot points, I must say The James is another good reason why not to use Marriot points at least when staying in New York City. From the time you walk through the doors, The James and it great team including Christy, Jessica, Louis, and CK all lead by an exceptional executive management team, truly make you feel like you are at home in the middle of one of the most unique and incredible neighbors in the world, So Ho. Now, add the David Burke Kitchen with David’s amazing Porter House for two, the coolest drinks like the Honey Badger, the Concierge service and this is one hotel I am sure you will be coming to time and time again. Great work to this exceptional customer focused team - you clearly have found the right recipe both in style and people! My wife and I just can’t wait to come back.

We stayed at The James for 8 or 9 nights so we came to think of the hotel as our home. I must admit at first I was a bit concerned about the size of our room. I get that NY was always going to be tight for space but we didn't have a lot of room for our luggage (that could be us though...2 large suitcases for a 5 week trip). Having said that, this was our only concern. The staff, the facilities,the room, the decor, the lobby...it was all perfect. And we loved being in such a nice neighborhood. Away from the tourist areas of Midtown but in the heart of great shopping, eating and entertainment. The David Burke Kitchen was a real highlight for dinner as well.

From check-in to departure, our experience at The James was fantastic. The hotel is located in the perfect location. Close to shopping and restaurants - located in a real New York City local neighborhood. The hotel design both in and out is just perfect. The rooms are spacious and well appointed. We were lucky enough to get a room on the 16th floor with amazing views of Manhattan through the large floor to ceiling windows. We checked in late and had not had a chance to eat dinner so we ordered room service. It arrived in record time and was absolutely delicious. The staff was very professional and friendly - making us feel welcome.

We just returned from a 4 night stay in the James Hotel in New York. We were lucky enough to be given a corner room on the 17th floor – this offered fantastic views over midtown including the Chrysler, USB and Brooklyn Bridge. Check-in was quick, easy and efficient and the staff were friendly and professional.Our room apart from the fantastic views was also clean and comfortable. The rainfall shower was great. The bed was very comfortable and a choice of pillows was available. The chocolates left during turndown was a nice touch as wellIt was a nice touch that in the lobby at various times through the day , coffee, pastries fruit and wine were available – it was a nice relaxing atmosphere in the evening with guests sitting about enjoying a glass of wine. Only went to Jimmy’s one evening – nice enough – again great views across lower Manhatten including the Freedom Tower. Also went to the Treetop Bar one evening which was ok. We didn’t eat in the hotel so I can’t commentThe location was great with all of Soho on your doorstep and entrance to Canal St metro station literally just round the cornerReally enjoyed our stay and especially found the staff to be friendly and courteous

We spent 5 days at the James in November. The staff was great! They were very friendly and were always willing to help us get around. The room we were in was small, great for 2 people but we squeezed 3 (2 adults and 1 child). The room itself was very clean and the bed was comfortable to sleep on after a long day of sight seeing. The bathroom had heated floors and oraganic/gluten free beauty products. We spent most of the day out of the hotel but every morning there were scones available to the guests in the lobby and each night when we returned there were cookies (which was a big hit with my daughter). This was our first stay at the James but will stay there again in the future.

My husband and I stayed at The James for a long weekend December 14-17. We loved the hotel and would stay here again. Our friend lives in the West Village so we were within walking distance of her, great restaurants, bars, shopping, music etc.. The hotel itself is beautifully appointed and the staff was great. The rooms are not huge but there was plenty of space for two. When we were in the room we slept well. The beds were warm and comfy. We had a room on an upper floor so we had a great view. We walked all over The Village, Soho, Little Italy and had a great time with SantaCon. Sunday night we had tickets to a show at City Winery. It was so nice to be able to walk there and enjoy a great evening of music, comedy etc. (John Wesley Harding's Cabinet of Wonders). It was a great way to spend our last evening!  I would love to come back in the Spring when The James is utilizing their outdoor spaces. It looked like a fun place to hang out in nice weather.

My teenage daughter and I stayed at the James last month and really enjoyed everything about our stay there. The staff is wonderful and took the time to welcome us and always had the time to talk and help us plan our next outing. The room was beautiful. Comments about it's size is true but it was a reasonable size for NYC and so wonderfully decorated that it was just so great to enjoy all the amenities.My daughter was just mesmerized by the shower and bathroom. There is a see thru glass wall from the room to the shower area, however privacy can be obtained by pushing a button and lowering a privacy screen that is also a work of art. The shower itself was a rain shower design and the organic beauty products provided for free were wonderful.The room attendant took great care cleaning and freshening the room each day. David Burke's restaurant was great but geared towards those who like very spicy comfort food. The service was impeccable. Another perk was the house car that is available to drive you to your destination for free (of course we tipped the driver). The driver was so polite and kind and took us all the way to our Broadway play since no one was waiting for him at the hotel and the concierge told him it was okay. What a treat!If you are planning a trip to NYC you should definitely consider staying at the James. Their rates may see high but we were able to get a great deal that included breakfast. They offer fresh fruit,cookies, croissants, etc. all day for guests too. You will enjoy the art work, the staff's kindness and ability to help, the amazing comfortable beds, well I could go on and on! We will be back there as soon as possible!

We had an experience to remember staying at the James when Hurricane Sandy hit. We checked in on Saturday, we had to wait for our room but it was worth the wait, great views down to the financial district. The location of the hotel is great, fantastic shopping, huge choice of places to eat. Before Sandy hit we got note from management re-assuring us that the hotel had generators and not to be concerned, but to keep the curtains drawn. When the power did go off on Monday evening we found the generators were severely lacking - lights in the fire escape and corridors only, no power or lights to rooms, no lifts, and most importantly no water. We must commend the staff, all pulled together to move as many people as possible to hotels with power, on Tuesday. Taxis were not to be found and for blocks there were no traffic lights or police controlling traffic. The staff drove us themselves in their own cars, for which we are truely grateful. The hotel they moved us to initially seemed nice, though the attitude was condescending. However there was obviously a mix up of some sort, the new hotel thought we were going back to the James the next day, the James thought we were there for the rest of our stay (another 2 nights). Anyway we ended up tossed on the street, our only option to get out of New York all together. We give the benefit of the doubt about the mix up to the James because the staff did seem sincerely to be trying to help.

Nice hotel. Complementary muffins/scones and coffee at breakfast time, fruit in the afternoon and wine, cheese and crackers at night! Modern room. Not very spacious but big enough. Nicely located in Soho, practically next to a subway station. Quite a busy boulevard right next to it (avenue of the Americas, 6th avenue) which does produce some noise, especially during the daytime! Cleanliness was average.

Just got back from a weekend trip with my girlfriend, and we were both extremely pleased with The James. The staff were extremely helpful and courteous in all aspects (ie checking in/out, getting taxi's for us, making restaurant reservations). The delicious cookies served upon checking in is a nice touch, as was the fact that checkout is not until 2pm. The rooftop bar/lounge is beautiful with nice panaromic view of the city, and the pineapple mojitos were amazing. Rooms were very modern and elegant...definately coming back here.

This was our first visit to NYC with our four teenage grandchildren. The purpose was to visit NYC and view the Macy's Thanksgiving parade. The staff wasover and above the call of duty in helping us with the logistics of setting up to get a great viewing spot. The time, 6:00 am was a little early, but necessary to pick your spot. Rooms were ready when we arrived at 8:30 am th morning before the parade. Very convenient, very clean, and a very friendly staff. We WILL stay here on our next NYC>

Well we arrived in NYC with great anticipation to stay at the james. I had read reviews in magazines and online. It was a second trip in 18 months to NYC previously staying at the Crosby street hotel (which was fantastic.) This hotel should be fantastic, but the staff let it down. The only staff member to acknowledge us in our 8 day stay was Jessica. The concierge were too busy watching TV on there computers or speaking to each other to welcome you or bid you goodbye, asking for a cab was met with you can go on the corner and call one. Alarm bells should of rung when I tried to organise restaurants by email this was to become a two phone call chase up from Australia as it seems Luis could not get back to me with my requests and questions. This was finally fixed up and yes we did get our reservations.Cleaners took my washing without consent only for the staff not to know where it was (finally found) Every night we were asked for turn down at 6.30 and every night we said that we were going out at 8.15. Clearly 6.30 would be the most obvious time when people are getting ready to go out. The cleanliness of the room was average, we did find squashed M&Ms behind the curtian.The location for this hotel is fabulous with wonderful views, however it is only 3 years old and is feeling the test of time.I may have had my expectations set a little bit high coming off a wonderful stay at the crosby the previous year. My Husband and I came away from this experience, thinking it was so close but yet so far...... a little bit of staff training would help.

From the moment you walk in the door, the service and friendliness of each member of The James staff was exemplary. Our room on the 15th floor was quiet, beautiful, very clean, and had great views down to the river. I can't say enough about the friendliness of everyone we met here. All of them genuinely made us feel so welcome to be here. We were here 4 nights for an event at the Barclay's Center in Brooklyn and it was an easy commute there as well. We're looking forward to our next stay.

We've just stayed at The James for almost a week and loved it. The hotel is very clean, modern, well decorated and the rooms well appointed. Staff are all very helpful and friendly. The location is great too, with plenty of shops, bars and restaurants nearby. A subway stop is available closeby. We were given a local map with all the shops, bars and restaurants on. It was a lifesaver on a few occasions! Navigation not being one of my strong points. The room itself was nice and as mentionned by previous reviewers the bathroom and its vanity screen was quite a novelty! The bed and pillows were very comfortable. Plenty of fresh water available and a turndown service. My favourite perk of the hotel was the little treats available in the lobby. At breakfast there was coffee and scones, fresh fruit and water in the afternoon and wine, cheese and crackers in the evening. What a great idea! We used the rooftop bar on several occasions and loved it too. Stunning setting, good cocktail list and attentive staff. Our only criticism was re the David Burke Kitchen, but I wouldn't let this cloud my rating of the hotel. For breakfast, Le Pain Quotidien on Grand St offered a nice selection of pastries, breads, eggs and oatmeal. For something more, Balthazar on Spring St also enjoyable.

I have to write that the doormen Felix and Mike were an amazing help today when no cabs would actually agree to take me to a Newark Hotel near the airport. God bless the doormen as they kept trying to help me! I even got into two cabs who kicked me out, one of which took me, thought I was going to the Newark airport and 5 blocks into the trip when he found out I was going to an airport hotel instead, turned me around and dropped me back at The James. Mike was just getting off shift when he went above and beyond by offering the option of commuting with him home to Jersey on the subway/bus and his wife would pick us up at the other side and personally drive me to my destination. Amazing. But it gets better - a colleague named Mimi, graciously gave Mike her car so that he could drive us to Newark instead. Now that's going above and beyond for your clientele. Thank you so much Mike, Felix and Mimi for leaving a very positive impression and actually caring about my predicament :) Much appreciated! It's nice to know there are genuinely good people out there!

Met my BF from high school at The James New York this week overnight and had a fabulous time! The hotel is really beautiful and located in a great area of Soho. Walking distance to so much. The room was very fun with the ceiling to floor windows, glass bathroom (with vanity screen that can be electronically lowered from the bathroom) and super comfy beds/pillows. It's a very "green" hotel and beautiful architecturally.The staff were so accommodating and there for our every need. Assisted us in finding the places we wanted to go with maps, how to get there and room service was ridiculously fast.Jimmy's on the rooftop is a classy, fine time with a stunning view at night. David Burke's Kitchen was delicious for breakfast but our waitress was unacceptably slow and moody. We were the only ones there besides one other table that was leaving when we arrived and we waited almost 30 minutes to pay our bill after eating. Our only complaint.Overall, it is the 5 star hotel that was recommended to us by many and it did not disappoint minus the breakfast service.

Lovely Hotel in Soho. Our room was delightful, with a modern design, very comfortable bed and pilllows and the shower was fabulous with large shampoo, conditioner and bath gel dispensers. The hotel location is close to many restaurants, bars and great shopping boutiques. One of favorite pubs nearby, the Broome Street Bar has great affordable food and drinks with history and charm. The service at The James was impeccable, from the front desk staff, housekeeping and bellman. One of the amenities I loved was the triple filtered water supplied in room and refreshed daily, what a nice perk! I loved our stay and will visit again.

Super friendly welcome from concierge, reception and more or less every employee we met. The room was average size, nice bed and great bathroom. We were near the lift which meant things were noisy through the night. Fantastic views over the city. Didn't go to the bar as we had a pretty hectic schedule outside the hotel, but seemed to be nice. It didn't suit our schedule this time location wise but if I had business or pleasure in that part of town again I'd stay. We found it pretty expensive but couldn't fault the interiors or service.

The James Hotel New York is located in the midst of Soho, a short walk to Chinatown and only steps to the subway.. great position. We stayed for ten days, the hotel itself was great fun and friendly, the young staff were delightful and we were happy to see that they catered to pets, we met many (large) dogs in the lift and elsewhere around the lounge. The outdoor restaurant was good as was the pool on the roof which had fabulous views of the city and was usually full of beautiful people partying (there's an adjacent bar). However the rooms were ordinary, immediately upon arriving we upgraded from a queen to a king sized room. Even the king room was small; this was not a five star experience, nor could we sleep very well, there was continuous banging on the roof just above us. Although we loved much about the Hotel I doubt we'd return, after busy days in NYC we wanted quiet, luxury and comfort and we found this when we moved uptown to "The Pierre".

I stayed a night at the James after losing power at home during Hurricane Sandy and can't say enough good things about this place.The service was very warm, the room was gorgeous, the vibe was great and the rooftop bar and restaurant are terrific.If you need to spend a night at a hotel in the Soho area, check this place out - it's a treat for the senses.

This hotel is such a disappointment. The rooms are ok, we have a Corner Queen with a great bed, nice bathroom but it's not a five star room experience, rather a 3 star+. The view is ok but not super impressive. The location is great, no doubt about it. Ok, hotel itself is nothing special at all and I've stayed at a quite a few. Now we have the service - hallelujah, TOTAL FAIL. Don't expect anything more than the ordinary. The staff is nice but not trained in a five star fashion, rather a two star.Check in: I arrived by time for check in and had asked for a high floor room. I was told it was going to take an hour so I said ok. After 30 minutes i was told it was going to take 2 hours so I skipped the high floor. My girlfriend (who hade made the reservation) arrived in the evening. She was told the room was already occupied and then there was that little, but still clear, hint that maybe she was a call girl. No one said that but the way she was treated was to hear discriminating (here we have a woman who has travelled the world and never has experienced anything like that)Getting an adapter: I had forgotten an adapter and asked for one. They were all occupied by guests I was told but "soon" I would get one. I had a board meeting and needed computer as well as mobile (which I explained) and needed power. If it was urgent I was asked to walk five blocks to buy one (It was snowstorm in NY this day) After two hours and several calls still no adapter. I was now running out of battery and had to stop the conf call. I was upset now and called back but no reaction. When I 15 min later was furious, called and asked them to send someone "to buy 20 adapters for the hotel and I pay for them" it was some action. First when I offered myself to buy for the hotel I got an adapter. Wow, what a five star treatment.......I was calm and really nice up until then.The remote: After having to stop the board meeting due to no power I thought I watch some tv. does the remote work? Of course not.......and remember we're talking about a five star hotelThe hotel manager: I called the hotel manager but he didn't seem to care at all to be honest. The James is a hotel that can charge high prices just because their location. I can never ever recommend anyone to stay here unless you need to get really upset. It's an ok hotel but for the same money you can have a really really nice experience somewhere else

I chose The James New York because of its location and interior design. It was my first time in SoHo and took a chance based on TripAdvisor rankings.And what a great choice! Service: Michael the bellman was great for tips, recommendations and solutions! The hotel provides a free car service, and Rick the driver was more than accommodating.Room: Appreciated the eco-friendly features like water in carafes instead of plastic bottle, Intelligent Nutrients toiletries in refillable containers (personal-sized version upon request). Unfortunate that housekeeping changed my towel and bed linen though. The power strip is a thoughtful gesture that a world traveller like myself appreciates.Loved the bathroom shade!Food: breakfast at David Burke Kitchen sets a wonderful tone for the day! (Dinner was the most flavorful and satisfying I had on this trip as well.)Location: SoHo's the best place to explore in NYC! And these are why am coming back to The James for more.

Nicely decorated hotel and staffed with excellent employees.The rooms feature many light modification functions. Great views on the upper floors. The food catering by the restaurant kitchen is also excellent.ik and JJiljalon@aol.com
user_name:
ILJA K
New York City, New York

review_body: This will be our Hotel of Choice in Manhattan for all future visits. Nothing was less than exceptional, in terms of Location, Quality of Accomodations, and Cleanliness; however, two areas this Hotel stands out in are Service and their Rooftop Bar/Pool Area, not to mention their Star Restaurant and Green Terraces. My wife and I have often found, some of smaller, boutique Hotels, simply try harder, and The James does that and more. The James is the type of accomodation that leaves you trying to change your Travel Plans to stay just one more day!

Visited couple of times since opening. Seems to me that it's following the typical pattern: start of great, get popular, than develop attitude and stop listening to feedback by guests. After sending in a serious complaint after horrendous stay to GM, all I got was a one line reply by assistant front-desk employee and USD 50 to spend on food on my next stay?! No way! I would say, brace yourself for the party weekends, not being listened to and overpaying. Better value for money to be found nearby.

This hotel is SoHo (South of Houston) - is worth the price. The room and views are great! Definitely for couples, business people traveling alone, or friends who are comfortable being very close.Hotel rooms in NYC are tiny and these are no exception, but they make the most of the space and room amenities are great! If you can afford it - stay here :) Also, they were very helpful in every way with customer service. The view from the roof bar - Jimmy at the James - is breathtaking. Definitely make your way up there.

Staff were fantastic from start to finish. Room was small (typical NYC) but very well designed and laid out that we never felt crammed. Beautiful bath, very comfortable bed and sound-proof windows (helps with crazy cabbie honking going on 24/7). great mood lighting options in the room (huge benefit to boutique hotels). Rooftop access at Jimmy was great - fantastic views of the whole city surrounded by cool decor/people/drinks.no breakfast - which is fine with us as we like to eat out - why else go to NYC? They do offer some fresh baked goods and coffee in the lobby - which was a beautiful area to hang out.Artwork throuhout the hotel was also a nice feature to appreciate.Great place... excellent staff... great location and good value (for a boutique hotel). Would definately stay again if i stay in SOHO.

I stayed here with my husband and baby of 7 months. I rang before hand to make sure they had my request for a cot. Which they didFirst impressions hotel modern and new. The rooms are small for 2 adults and a baby. The cot they gave was horrible. Had metal railings with no bumpers on the side for protection. The first night he slept in there. He hurt himself. So for the remaining 3 nights he was in bed with us. New York isn't a place for staying in but this is our 6th trip and first with baby. And I found this hotel not to be child friendly. U need to catch 2 elevators to get to the lobby if u have a pushchair. Would not recommend and will defiantly stay at my first choice which was the trump soho.

Spent 4 nights here. With my dog, Goose. The desk staff was very friendly, totally professional & they all seem to love dogs, which helps. Most of the door guys are cool & friendly & helpful. The room was very comfortable, the bed is outstandng & the view (Hudson side) was mesmerizing. The restaurant is really good (lower level); run by a tv show chef. The bar on the roof employs several bartenders who you may want to just smack on the noggin, because they have an arrogant, pouty, you-owe-me attitude. Always odd to encounter that from someone in the hospitality / service biz. There's a difference between being a tool & being insouciant: these boys haven't figured out what it is yet. In any event, the bar gets packed with see & be-seens. Worth going once for a drink, then spending your time, and money, elsewhere. Tons of restaurants close by, obviously tons of shopping in Soho. Room was quiet, clean. Definitely would recommend for a stay if you want to be near Soho.

Wonderful hotel with excellent location. Very nice service. We had the fortune to get a corner room at the top floor with glass from floor to ceiling. Really nice view. The sleeping comfort was very high and the room intreior was very nice. Clearly recomend!

Second time staying at The James and it was again a great stay. It seems that the staff have gotten even better at being attentive and friendly! Our room wasn't ready at arrival so the front desk sent us to the bar for complimentary drinks and called us when the room was ready. Nice touch. The lobby area also always has snacks, coffee or wine for guests. The hotel is in a great location and walking distance to Tribeca and SoHo. The rooms are slightly bigger than other hotel rooms I've stayed in in New York. The corner rooms are great, with great views, a lot of windows and light.The only complaint I have was that we were in a room right below Jimmy's bar on the 17th floor (room 1708). The first night you could hear the music thumping - not loud but enough to be heard. The second night you could here furniture being moved around, I guess when it closed. The bar however is great and we were up there having drinks one night. Again friendly staff and amazing views of Manhattan!Will definitely stay at The James again!

We booked five nights through a booking site and found our corner king studio well worth the money. Location of the hotel is very good, on walking distance of a lot of nice restaurants, bars, shops, subway.... The staff is extremely friendly and helpful, in a sincere way. Having to take our breakfast in our room seamed a bit strange at first, but quite enjoyed that.Then our flight back home got cancelled and we had to extend our stay in NY by two days. We could extend our stay ... At $ 510 per day. We did enjoy staying at the hotel, but that's simple to expensive for this hotel, so we booked another hotel for the last two days

Loved staying at the James! We were there in August for 4 nights for my sister's wedding....so we booked multiple rooms at a group rate. My sister and her husband had a beautiful suite on the top floor, it had a separate living room area and it was very spacious, but expensive. We were in a corner room on the 9th floor...our room had an adjacent room for my parents with a little private foyer separating the rooms. This was the perfect set-up for us because we could store the baby stroller in the foyer each night. Or we could leave our doors open but close the main door that lead out to the hallway. The rooms were small but bright and I loved the bathroom and all of the products they supplied. In addition, the nightly turn-down service was a really nice touch. We always got different gourmet chocolates left next to the bed, and extra bottles of filtered water.The staff was extremely helpful throughout our entire stay. They knew our group, and allowed us to reserve the terrace of the treehouse one evening for an "after-rehearsal-dinner party". They also reserved the treehouse for our brunch the morning after the wedding. Upon arrival, when my parents' room was not ready, they offered a credit at the David Burke restaurant. We all ate there and had a wonderful meal. Top notch food, drinks, and service. The room service food was good too, we had a complimentary continental breakfast each morning.In addition to the nice rooms and service, the hotel itself is really cool, beautiful and different. The lobby is simple but has a cool glass elevator to access it. The garden areas are amazing, and you can eat/drink out there or just relax. Finally the rooftop bar is really nice and the pool deck. Both are small but sufficient for downtown NYC. The views are magnificent.The location of the hotel was perfect.
