I've lost an entire day of a short, three-day vacation: one-third of my ENTIRE trip.The hotel has offered me nothing, not even a glass of wine or room service. I am stuck here feeling unsafe and all they will do is now say its a police matter and out of their hands.No one has promised to make this right. Everyone says some contrived, robotic statement like, "We will do our best to rectify the situation." That isn't what I want to hear; this isn't showing any leadership type of responsibility...this is falling some linear corporate rule book in a crisis situation when being creative and in charge is mandatory. No one on the staff can take accountability to me.I have no money and can't afford to fly home early. I can't leave my room because I feel so unsafe and that if I leave I will be violated again. A felony has been committed and I'm taking this matter extremely seriously but even though its blatantly obvious what happened, the hotel is acting like nothing happened.I would not stay here if it was the last place on earth.

i've stayed at the james a number of times since it opened. love the location, decor, restaurant / hang out spaces, touches like the tea/coffee/pastries in the morning. i'm a frequent traveler to NYC and have stayed at the mercer, crosby, soho grand, James.a few stays ago though, i did not get my scheduled wake up call which caused me to be very late for an important meeting. i mentioned it to the person at the front desk who apologized, and i assumed it was a one time mistake. but - on my stay this week, i did not get my scheduled wake up call on time or at all ALL OF 3 MORNINGS. i just can't believe it. the first day, it was 10 minutes late. yesterday, it was 15 minutes late. last night when i called to ask for a wake up call at 8:20am, i asked the front desk person specifically to please make sure i got a call because the previous 2 mornings i'd gotten my morning call 10-20 minutes late. i just got the call - it's 8:45am. for someone with jet lag who needs to get a morning meeting, that is just unacceptable. thank goodness i set my watch alarm expecting them to be late. for a hotel charging over $500/night, i am shocked that this one area is so unprofessionally done. James hotel please fix this - business travelers need to be able to count on you.

This was the second time we stayed at the James this year (the first time was in April this year). I must say that the staff is MUCH friendlier and extremely helpful (perhaps all the negative reviews had a postive impact?). We loved the room, the wooden floors and the awesome bathroom. My partner and I chose an angle room and unfortunately we were given a room on the 3rd floor where the views are disappointing compared to the higher floors.The roof top bar was breathetaking: wow that view! Unfortunately, the room cleaning was disappointing: thourough cleaning is a must for a hotel of this standard.

The room was exactly like my grad school dorm...stark and cold with cheap furnishings. The bed was acceptable but the air conditioner was not producing a constant temp. so the room got hot then air kicked on until too cold then warmed up again to the point of feeling the need to kick off covers. Does not make for a good nights sleep.

My husband and I stayed at the James Hotel in early October and had a fantastic time. The only was regret was not carving out more time to spend in the hotel.We went to NY to celebrate a special occasion and were surprised to find the hotel staff has a special treat waiting for us in our room. This was a fantastic way to start our trip, especially after a late night flight from L.A. I also enjoyed the short ride on the glass elevator up to the lobby, where I’m told they have coffee and pastries in the morning, some kind of snack during the day, and wine in the evening. Every hotel employee we encountered was happy to help us whenever we had a question or request, especially the doormen. They helped us with car service to the airport, which is way better than a cab and surprisingly not too pricey—ask about it. There are also cool orange bikes in the lobby for use. We upgraded to a corner room, and it was totally worth the extra $$. Even though we didn’t have the curtains open all the time, the view was incredible when we did. Speaking of views, the rooftop bar is not to be missed, especially at sunset. We are in our early thirties, and found the crowd to be somewhat hipsterish, yes, but not annoying—if that combination is possible. There were certainly guests in the hotel who did not fit that description in the least and seemed to be getting along just fine. We went up there a couple times and it was actually pretty peaceful. Take your camera.As for the room, the bed was hands down the most comfortable I have slept in. Ever. My husband is a frequent world traveler and he agreed. We liked the big rainfall shower as well. A bathtub would have been nice, but space is at a premium, of course. Housekeeping did a great job and we were happy to return to our room every day. I also enjoyed the carafe of filtered water the hotel left for us near the bed. My only gripe is that one night our phone was not working and all we wanted to do was order room service, but we didn’t have the energy to complain, so I can’t fault the hotel as they didn’t even know the problem existed. As I had consumed a moderate amount of alcohol that night, I probably would have ordered something I would regret in the morning. So perhaps the universe was looking out for me. Neighborhood is great. In the heart of Soho, very close to the subway, and easy stroll to West Village to hang out, or head the other way to Little Italy when you have a craving for cannoli, which is right now. Speaking of food nearby, we had breakfast/brunch twice at a place around the corner on Broadway called Sanctuary T, which I highly recommend. There’s a place a few doors down from that called the Cupping House that has good Eggs Benedict. We popped in to Café Noir, right across the corner from the hotel for a late night snack and were not impressed. They actually forgot about us after 2 rounds of drinks and never took our order. David Burke Kitchen (in the hotel) seemed like a great place, but the menu was not really exciting for a vegetarian so we passed, much to my carnivore husband’s dismay.Thank you to The James. We will gladly return.

Ignore the review by "Disappointing"- - we just returned from a 3 night trip here and it was superb. Staff could not have been more friendly and helpful. Guests have full access to the roof top bar from when it opens at 5pm. After 9-ish you need to book for a seat but you won't be turned away of you are happy to stand. It was our 10th wedding anniversary and the complementary bottle of champagne was a great touch. Beds are very comfortable and air con works well, rooms bright and light. Location is fantastic with a load of great bars and restaurants on your doorstep. Plenty of shopping on West Broadway etc if that flicks your switch.

Staff more bothered how they look than how they treat their guests. Small rooms. No evening turn down service (should do but do not bother. Complained twice.). Only 1 bar (bar upstairs with pool is only open after 9.30pm and only if your on the guest list). Usually stay in similar boutique hotel, but this is the worst I have stayed in and would recommend you chose another.
Hotel perfect for soho shopping trip. Hotel is very modern and has a great rooftop gym and bar. David Burke restaurant was ok. The concierge gave great dining recommendations.

Modern, metropolitan and minimalist. Impeccable as few are able to consistently be, effortlessly luxurious with a genuinely attentive service. If you learned to appreciate this recipe at the James Chicago you will be pleased to find it in New York too. It's all those little unexpected touches that get you to L O V E the James New York. I won't list them because the discovery journey is part of what make you smile. Whether you have been to NYC many many times and you want to breath Soho in or this is your first visit, the James is a MUST.

I stayed at your hotel last week. I tremendously enjoyed staying at the James hotel and wanted to provide some good feedback based on my experience with you guys.the reason I went there was because of the special offer "See ART WITH THE JAMES"The curator,Matt was very helpful and courteous, the guided tour was really helpful especially for those first time visitors because sometimes some people feel intimidated with a new setting. All staffs were very friendly and proactive trying to help me out. eg) Booking a restaurant for me. Providing me a car service to a certain location,so on That positive attitude makes your hotel stand out among others. I was so impressed by your staffs promptness and proactive attitude. Keep up the good work. :) I'll definitely stay at your hotel while visiting NY. Again, Thank you Sincerely,

I liked The James quite a bit. The rooms are smallish, but not insanely so, and well laid out, and the bathrooms are very nice. The housekeeping is very friendly, but a little spacy (I had to call to have them come clean the room once). All the staff is VERY VERY nice and helpful, though -- especially the door men. The hotel has free wine and cheese in the afternoon, and BEST OF ALL: free coffee and pastries in the morning! Which is excellent if you're there for work and don't have time for a proper breakfast. The bed is VERY comfy and the location is great. You will like it,Note: I was there on business, and the James inadvertently screwed up my bill (they charged the room to my personal card rather than to the company). They fixed this promptly and cheerfully -- I am very happy with the way the mistake (an honest one) was handled.

This was my first stay at The James and I highly recommend it to anyone looking for a hotel in NYC. It is located in Soho just above Canal street with great shops, restaurants and clubs right outside their front door. The room was very nice, clean and comfortable. My favorite part, which is a little hard to explain, the bed was raised off the floor and there were no corner legs or side edges to stub your toes on. I know it's weird but this is a problem for me in unfamiliar locations. The service from the front door, to reception, to room service and housekeeping was fabulous. I believed that every employee working there truly liked working there and wanted to be of great service. I was not able to make it to the rooftop bar but I heard it is very cool.

We really liked this place. The concierge and lobby staff were really helpful and friendly - the lobby and rooftop bars were perfect places to hang out. It's right by a subway station and also walkable to Downtown sites and on a strip of good restaurants. They provide complimentary delicious pastries in the morning, fruit in the day, wine in the evening and cookies at night. On the downside, the room wasn't ready even though they knew our check in time, the rooms were abit small and although we paid a higher rate for a higher room, we were only on the 14th floor - and it is quite expensive for a middle level view.

Due to London fashion week there was little choice by way of hotels. A colleague booked us into the James. It was expensive but the location, fit out, restaurant and service more than lived up to the price.On the minus side the rooms were very small, but this is normal in NYC I believe.On the plus sides the service was attentive (although there was an issue over laundry - be sure to call them to pick up), the gym was lovely and all the restaurants/ bars were top notch.Would definitely return, not least for its proximity to Soho and great shopping.

That's not to say the room wasn't clean -- just that housekeeping was erratic and kind of unobservant. For instance, the clock in my room stopped working -- it was blinking back and forth from a blank screen to scrambled color bars -- so I took to turning it face-down on the table (you couldn't unplug it) and putting a newspaper over it. And every day housekeeping would come by and turn it upright again, yet apparently never seemed to notice that it was broken despite that being glaringly obvious. Now, in fairness, I never remembered to call about it, so I'm sure the hotel would've sent someone up to fix it, but it is also sort of indicative of my experience with housekeeping here that they repeatedly put the clock back in place and never did anything about it being so clearly broken. They also didn't regularly empty wastebaskets, and the room smelled like smoke when I arrived. It took two calls down to the front desk to get a remote fixed. Stuff like that. They just were kind of spacey.However, the front-desk staff and the bellhops were super nice -- in fact, the housekeepers were nice too -- and the hotel is in a great location, right near both the red and blue lines on the subway and with tons of good eateries around, plus an all-night deli across the street that makes great sandwiches. The bed was comfortable, and if the pictures of the bathroom with the glass wall freak you out, it's okay: There is a motorized shade you can put down with the flip of a switch. The chair at the tiny table is ridiculously uncomfortable -- the pad they put it on it is not large enough, so the metal frame dug into my legs; classic example of choosing design over comfort -- but you can solve that by sitting on the leather banquette instead, which also has two drawers underneath it that were ideal for storing clothes. The closet size was fine, but there are never enough hangers in hotels, and this was no exception.We will totally stay here again, though. All these are things that can be lived with or corrected.

Seriously this has to be the best hotel in NYC. It's located in SoHo near all the shops and restaurants and also near a train line if you need to be someplace else. Don't take the train? Well there's a free car service to get you where you need to go. The rooms are small but what room isn't in NYC? The bathrooms are super cool with the rainfall shower head and the really nice toiletries. There's also a movable shade if you're the shy type and don't want your roomie or significant other to see you in various states of undress through the all glass enclosure. The lobby and business center area are both well designed and decorated. You feel like you're in someone's swank loft lounging around using the computer or having a drink on the couch than in a hotel. I've stayed at the James a few times now and each time there was a celeb hanging out in the lobby.The gym at the top of the hotel is adequate to get a decent workout in. Lots of combo type machines where you pull levers to do for example a chest press then a shoulder press. There's a cable pulley as well with various attachments and a few treadmills. The great thing about the gym is that its on a high floor and you can see all of lower Manhattan through the windows. It's a great place for a workout.One advice...make sure you go to the rooftop bar and have two cocktails. My friends in NY tell me that everyone who lives in the city tries to find a way to bar since that's where the cool kids hangout. By staying at the hotel and flashing a room key you get instant access. Enjoy it.

The hotel is small, but nicely appointed. An oddly shaped property means that the lobby is not on the ground floor and there's an assortment of elevators that lead to different levels of the building. The feeling succeeds in being more boutique-like than confusing though. Our request for an early check-in could not be accommodated due to check-outs but the staff tried. The room on the 10th floor (1003) looking south toward downtown was pretty and the shower was delightfully spacious. A/C worked great. Not a lot of space to put things down in the rooms... a small table and just a little counter space. The FREE WIRELESS throughout the hotel was great, fast, and appreciated. David Burke Kitchen is slightly pricey for what you get and the waffles were disappointingly heavy. The Kitchen was the least exciting part of the stay. The upstairs club and "splash" pool are nice but often crowded with hipsters and if they're playing any kind of live music the area is so small there's no where to escape it. We ordered massages and the "spa" was the least impressive part of the stay... the hotel hires out for their masseuses. The quality of the massage was good but the price is way too expensive. You would expect the full spa (showers/baths/steam) for what you pay but you only get a rather pedestrian pop-up tent called the Cabana. Noise from the outdoor dining patio just thirty feet away overpowers the music played for your massage. I would definitely recommend seeking spa facilities elsewhere where you will get more bang for your buck. Room service was good and timely, and everyone was friendly. I would stay again if I had to be in the same area, though I'm likely to try a couple more SoHo hotels first just to compare.

From the staff's uniforms to the rooftop pool, the James is a dream. Very convenient location in SoHo with many shops, bars, restaurants within walking distance. The rooms are good sized for NYC standards. Clean, comfortable, and a modern design. Mornings are spent in the lobby's lounge for free pastries and coffee. And afternoons with cheese & wine to relax before dinner. Feel like some croquet in the garden? They've got that for you, too.The staff is beyond friendly, helpful, & knowledgeable. Amazing place, would highly recommend it.

This is a great hotel, no doubt about it. It's a good mixture of location, style and unobtrusive but excellent service - the owners have really perfected the boutique hotel concept in my opinion. Upsides: cool rooms with excellent views. A cracking gym that is small but with views across Soho that will keep your mind occupied on any given boring treadmill run. Excellent food, cool and engaging staff...it's all there. Down sides: we were charged $16 per connected call (even if the call just hit voicemail and you hung up) which meant when we checked our bill in more detail, we'd been charged around $100 for telephone calls that didn't happen. The rooftop bar in the hotel "The Jimmy" is a little too cool for school and the woman serving behind the was pretty aggressive (or maybe pretty and aggressive!) but I guess that just goes with the territory. All in all it was a brilliant stay and I can comepletely recommend this place, particularly for couples. We certainly hope to return.......

I joined my boyfriend on a business trip to NY and we stayed and "The James"- what can I say....we travel a lot and stay in a lot of hotels but this was really one of the most outstanding ones so far. Normally I never have time to write reviews - or didn't find it necessary - but in this case I really wanted to write one as we were so positively surprised that I wanted to share it. What we experienced in The James was outstanding - In terms of service, location (in Soho, close to Chinatown, WT1, and 1 min walk to the next metro station), value for money and nice staff.From beginning to the end of our stay the staff was very friendly and helpful - it really felt more like friends than service staff. The room (we had a big corner deluxe room) was very nice and the view over NY even better. Nice bathroom with nice rain fall shower and a very nice shampoo (really liked the smell :) ) An even better, amazing view was from the roof top pool bar - astonishing!! And here as well - very nice service and it is really special to swim in a pool and have a look over NY/ to the Hudson. The hotel offers free!! cookies & coffee in the morning, fruits & water during the day and cheese & wine in the evening - we really enjoyed the wine in the evening before going out for dinner! Furthermore they have 2 bikes to rent for hotel guests - we made use of that on our last day which was really nice...the hotel is just about 2 blocks from the Hudson river and then you can drive along there ....wonderful - one more short note - I also really liked the outfits/design of the staff, nice, natural, 30's and fitted very well with the whole interior of the Hotel. I would definitely recommend the hotel and we will for sure come back here at our next stay in NY.
Try to get above fourth floor and enjoy the neighborhood.
Stayed during Irene and the staff handled the situation great. Location good -- on the edge of SoHo. Outdoor bar looked fun. I will stay here again.

Super-friendly service in the midst of uber-hipster posing is one of the lovable contradictions at the James New York. Enjoy the spectacular views from the the floor-to-ceiling windows, the complimentary coffee at breakfast and wine at cocktail hour, the great location and the view from the roof. Roll your eyes at the thoroughly unprofessional restaurant and the hit-or-miss housekeeping.It's clear that this is a hotel for the under-30 crowd, but this older couple had a great time.

Rooms- Standard Ny room size=small. Clean, nice tiled shower, took a while to figure out there was a curtain that slides over the clear glass in the see through bathroom. Mini fridge with STD bar drinks & snacks. Couldn't find the price list so didn't want to buy a $20 pop just in case.Happy Hour- the free wine & cheese was nice. Continental Breakfast- that was a waste. Strong coffee & cinnamon buns. That's all I saw.Room Service- ordered pizza. It was good & quick. 15 minute service.Rooftop Bar- very trendy & nice. No complaints. Very dressy, noticed all the women wore a little black dress including the waitresses. Expect the Std. $20 NY drink. I was at the hotel for work.

While this place met most of our expectations, the service exceeded it! Every member of staff that I dealt with or ran in to was very, very attentive and helpful! There was a great vibe as a result of their cheerful helpfulness.The room itself was great - loved the minimal design and adored the view! The only minor issue was that the floor looked a bit dusty and the walls appeared scuffed inside the rooms - likely the result of luggage wheels hitting them and leaving those black rubber marks. The bathroom design was great too, and pretty clean, although parts of the tile had hard water stains. These were minor, and I was in town for a meeting, so it wasn't in any way a big deal. For the most part, this place exceeded our expectations and is a great base from which to explore - whether you are there as a tourist or on business!

My husband and I celebrated our 7th Anniversary at The James and the hotel and staff went above and beyond to make our stay memorable! Our room was gorgeous, a studio king corner suite with panoramic views of the city. The staff was unbelievably friendly and helpful. We were brought champage, chocolates, and a handwritten card wishing us a Happy Anniversary. Michael (a.k.a. Bradley Cooper) at the front desk took great care of us! After a night on the town, we headed to the Jimmy upstairs. Make sure to be placed on the list. Views and cocktails on the Jimmy's rooftop were spectacular (drinks were extremely pricey but worth it for the views!). I wanted a perfect weekend at a gorgeous hotel and The James delivered! It was a great boutique hotel with a great team to make your experience memorable. Thank you so much and we WILL be back!!

The hotel was perfect, the service and the staff were so nice and warm, they took care of everything we asked and did it with alot of caring. The location was perfect. The hotel have a nice pool on the last floor. We really enjoy every minute of the the staying. Highly recommended !!!

I stayed at The James for a week this past July. Overall I really loved the hotel but there were a couple of little things that weren't ideal. I'll start with the good stuff though!While my corner queen room was not huge, the windows were massive and let in an extraordinary amount of light. The opening windows were a great touch too for letting in some of the New York sights and sounds. The hotel has free wifi (which you have to log in to every time you use, but that's not too annoying), guest computers in the lobby lounge, and some really great spaces to sit and relax, including the croquet lawn!! Coffee and snacks are served in the lobby during the day, with wine and cheese served from 6pm - 8pm each evening. A really great touch! I'd usually stop off in the lobby on my way back to my room after a huge day for a reviving glass of Chardonnay. Unfortunately for me there was a family with three young children staying at the same time, and while the parents had a wine the children climbed all over the furniture and generally made a bit of a nuisance of themselves. I had to escape a couple of times as it was not at all relaxing.The rooftop bar, Jimmys, was a fabulous spot with sweeping views across the city, great bar staff, delicious cocktails and the best tuna tatar tacos I've ever eaten! The pool is open for hotel guests until 5pm - I thought this was a bit early to close on a couple of the really warm evenings, but the bar filled up pretty quickly from then on and they really wanted the swimsuit crowd gone so the party crowd could take over! It was also closed for private functions twice during my stay which was a pity.I only had breakfast at David Burke Kitchen (excluding the food I ate in the bar and around the pool which was excellent) and it wasn't that great for the price. There were better cafes within minutes for breakfast. Also all drinks in both bars were served in plastic glassware. Something I saw was quite common in NY. I think the quality of the plastic glassware was pretty poor though, such a disappointment to drink a great glass of champagne or wine in a thick rimmed plastic goblet.Probably my last irk was that there was no in-room compendium. I understand it was supposed to make the hotel super chic to just phone the lobby any time you needed a question answered, but sometimes you just was to look up what time the bars/restaurants open or close, what time check-out is, or the name of a local beauty salon/hairdresser etc. I love flicking through a good hotel compendium! Some of this info was available on the website. They did, however, provide a room service menu. My room did not have a lot of space - the wardrobe was small, there was nowhere to put my makeup or sponge bag in the bathroom and the huge mini-bar tray took up the only other surface space in the room (I eventually moved it to a cupboard above the wardrobe). But these are little things that aren't really deal breakers. The hotel space is lovely, plenty of art on the walls, a busy bar and restaurant scene, gorgeous green spaces for relaxing, and fabulous roof top pool with great views. The staff were all very helpful and genuinely keen to make sure we enjoyed our stay. I would definitely stay here again.

Two of us stayed for a long weekend Thursday through Sunday. We had the same check in experience that most others had where the room type we booked was not ready, but did we want another one on a lower floor or we could wait. A glass of wine was offered to us to enjoy in the lobby lounge. We finished that and headed up to the rooftop bar to have a snack. The rooftop area was gorgeous - lovely views of the city. Some of the expensive chairs were broken as was the pool - it was closed for repairs our entire stay. Too bad as that was one of the amenities that drew us to the property. Food and service from the bar were good - didn't like drinking $12/glass wine in a plastic wine glass, but that's a safety thing.The staff came to get us when the room was ready (very nice of them) and were brought to the room on the 17th floor just under Jimmy the rooftop club. Important note about 17th floor - you can hear all the sounds from the club above quite clearly and all the movement of food and ice to and from the club goes through the hallway right outside your room! If you are a light sleeper, do not accept a room on 17.The rooms have wood floors, lots of windows, good lighting, comfortable beds, nice bedding, excellent products from Intelligent Nutrients and good storage once you find it! The low bench by the window has drawers for clothes and there is also a small closet with a full-length mirror.The bathroom has a huge walk in shower with a hand held and overhead rain options. It has a glass wall that connects to the room with a shade that can be lowered if desired. It seems the floors have a heated option, but may be shut off in the warm months.Our package included daily in-room breakfast - no matter what we chose on the menu for pastries, we were always brought a variety of things. However, we found the quality of the pastries offered in the lobby were better.The service throughout the hotel was excellent, especially the staff at the front door! The hotel offers two things which makes them stand out - complimentary car service during the week (limited range from the hotel) and bicycles! We were going to walk to the shops down the street and Chis said "take our car service!" A Lexus SUV took us to our destination just like that! We took the bicycles, which are not just any bike, but Paul Frank bikes - out one afternoon - we went down the river path to the ferry to Governor's Island (free service) then rode across the Brooklyn Bridge, then back to Tribeca for lunch. Best: Staff, service, location, room size, room design, comfort, amenities, art in common areasLeast: Broken pool and pool chairs, room rate confusion, room on 17th floor, car service limited to week days

What a fantastic hotel. Went with 6 friends. Staff is the nicest in all of NYC and made all the difference. Rooms are very nice and well appointed. Food was great. JIMMY rooftop bar is cool (get in before 9, the doormen are jerks and don't want hotel guests up there). Location is great for soho, TriBeCa and wall street. I'll definitely stay there next time I go to NYC.

The hotel is very pretty in a great location however the management and staff have a long way to go before they have perfected a truly world class hotel experience. It is very clear that the focus is entirely on their "coolness" factor with their facilities and very little on making their guests happy. Upon check in I was not informed that to utilize any of the outdoor spaces, pool, Jimmys, greenhouse etc, you must reserve through front desk and still not likely to be accomodated. The attitude of employees at these locations was terrible. David Burkes breakfast is delicious however. Additionally, the cleaning continued to forget to replace my filtered water bottle they emphasize nor did they remember to replace towels. All in all a fine stay and pretty nice room, but there are many better options in Soho and TriBeCa at this price range that are focused entirely on their guest experience rather than press for how cool they are.

What a complete disappointed this hotel turned out to be. On the website it all looks great, big, wunderfull, bright, modern etc but these pictures are enormously deceiving! In fact this was the smallest down town NYC 400 usd per night room I have ever seen. The floors were already damaged in the room and instead of a luxury feel of a new hotel it already looked 10 years old. The pool upstairs is not a pool but a large bathtub and if you want 1 of the only 3 double beds you really have to reserve (!) like 6 weeks ahead. The pool is actually a rooftop bar so when you like to dip the pool after a days work it is not possible, it closes at 5 PM. Actually the hotel restaurants and bars are not really for the hotel guests but more for outside visitors and allthough staff is trying, you don't have the feeling you are actually a guest of your own hotel.

having heard about jimmys, and spending holidays in NYC, I convinced my husband to have some drinks at the place as soon as we got there, a guy by the door said Jimmys was hosting a private party that night, and that only "listed" people could get in. toobad he didnt have any list on his hands, and in any moment asked us if we have been invited... good thing is have we crossed the street and got to know the CAFE NOIR... that was a real treat for our night: awesome music, delicious food, friendly staff, trendy customers...never will go back to James or Jimmys, certainly will return to CAFE NOIR!!! Thank you disgusting guy on a suit by the hotel's door!!!

This hotel has nice touches and amenities, but not impressed with the room as a business traveler. The room was very small (yes, even for NY), but nicely laid out with modern decor. The bathroom was separated from the bedroom (hard to really call it two rooms) by a glass wall. There was an electric shade with a mural that could be lowered for privacy. Cool design, but too small for working in the room. The only place to sit was a small table with a tiny aluminum chair or a padded bench (see photo). The room was annoying, but I probably could have put up with it for the week. It was the room upkeep that pushed it over the top. The room had a single rug under the table, which was badly stained. And there was a hair clog in the shower drain - yuck. Not what I expected from a luxury boutique hotel. I checked out after one night.
user_name:
AlanGP
New York City, New York

review_body: I stayed at this hotel during Memorial Day weekend. I was very happy that I found this hotel. It is in good location in Soho. Jimmy's bar was good, although pricey, even for New York standards. The pool was great, and it was not packed, but that was probably due to the fact that it was still not advertised that it was open. The view from the top of the roof deck was amazing and definitely one of the best Manhattan views I have seen. Staff was helpful. Wine reception at night with cheese was definitely a good touch. The room was nice, although it did not have a bath. The bed was comfortable. It was a decent size room for New York standards. I was celebrating a friend's birthday and the hotel sent chocolates and champagne to us, which was a nice touch. Overall, I would recommend this hotel, but only if you can find a good rate. A standard rate seems to be between $350-$400, which is a LOT for this hotel.

We had a wonderful week in The James and really enjoyed the whole package: roof top with pool, great view and Jimmys Bar (excellent margheritas!), the fitness room as well as David Burke Kitchen, where they created very tasteful non-alcoholic cocktails for us. The rooms are well designed giving a more generous impression due to the glass wall separating the bathroom, and the shower was generous indeed. Nice! We felt very welcome and experienced excellent service.

This is a new hotel and was still finding its way when we stayed there but considering that everything went well. The pool on the roof wasn't yet open but it looked a very promising facility with a comfortable seating area and great views. Unfortunately the rooftop bar appears to have been contracted out to be run as a bar/night club so was only open in the evening when it attracted a lively and youngish crowd from outside (it had its own separate entrance and elevator from the street level). This meant that we couldn´t go up for a drink, for instance, at midday. We didn't eat breakfast in the hotel because we walked to our daughter and son-in-law who live nearby. However we understand from other guests we knew that it is more than adequate.Location is perfect within easy walking distance of all parts of lower Manhattan from China Town and South Street Seaport in the East to the riverside walks along the Hudson to the West, Wall Street in the South and the wonderful High Line Park to the North. And for shopping nothing can beat Lower Broadway, just around the corner!We got a great week-end deal, three nights for the cost of two nights.

nice room, great location, sadly it is let down by a couple of things:1 - the pool has very limited hours - 9am til 5pm... and when it is open its so packed with non residents it reminded me of the sealions at Pier 51 in San Francisco. In four days of hot hot weather I wanted to take the plunge, but couldnt. 2 - my flight was an evening one - I had to leave the bags all day and there were no facilities to change and shower before I left for the airport. I ended up changing in a cupboard in the basement - frankly for a hotel of this quality its an oversight - there ought to be a day room available.

So...the good stuff; great location, friendly staff. Room very nice though I would have liked a bath. Our 2 teenagers had an upgraded room so a big bed to share, rather than the normal queen size which we had. I like the coffee and yummy pastry in the lobby in the morning, and the cheese and wine in the later afternoon (though you do have to serve yourself and the coffee comes in paper cups). 10 out of 10 for people watching opportunities and our 19 year old's eyeballs were out on stalks! Does it live up to the hype as a place for your average tourist to stay? Nope, unless that is, you fancy yourself as a extra from Sex and the City or you meet the demographic for the rooftop bar. In which case, you will absolutely love it!!The reason we were disappointed...the thorny (and no doubt for the manager-oft repeated) issue of "The Pool" and Jimmy's bar. If you come in midwinter, this will not be a problem as a pool is not important. We came in late July early August and chose the hotel because we thought we might want chill out by the pool from time to time.Anyone booking this hotel should realise that the premises should be described as follows: "Happening bar with plunge pool (BTW-114 room hotel attached if you need to stay over)". In all my experience I have never come across a hotel with a pool that is less available to guests at the times they want to use it than non residents. The local (and pool free) glitterati must be sooo delighted. After 4 nights here during what has probably been the hottest part of the summer let me just describe my experience:Sunday 31st July. Back in from a hard day seeing the sights, temperature is mid 30's degrees C, high 90's fahrenheit. Think we have time for a quick dip to cool off at about 4.30. (pool scheduled to close at 5pm-how daft is that??) Cossie on, jump in the lift to the roof. Lift door opens...place utterly rammed, thumping music (DJ), pool surrounded by 20 and 30 somethings packed in like sardines. Picture a Playboy pool party (minus Hugh Heffner). The very friendly chap in charge could see the look of horror on our faces and said that guests could, in theory, turf non residents off the chairs and sunbeds or ask those sitting round the pool (feet dangling in the water) to move so that we could wedge our (well preserved but sadly middle aged) bodies in and sit "cheek to cheek" with other revellers. We politely declined. He told us that tomorrow it might not be quite so bad (no DJ booked), but that the pool may close later in the week for the odd private party. So far to my knowledge there was some sort of do for Broadway shows, and this evening an Italian TV company had the use of the place from 5-8.30. Soo...so far that's every night where something else is going on.....2nd August. I did venture up at 4pm...hurrah! Sunbed available. Lay on it. G&T "only" $16 without tip. Told at 4.30pm that the place was closing at 5. American PR for Italian TV do arrives...followed by cameraman doing initial set up shots. All highly amusing to watch, but still, why, having paid over $2500 for 2 rooms (or should I now say $2516) we, the paying punters, take second place to the non residents and the hotel's self regarding PR machinations. Being the latest big thing is self evidently short lived and ephemeral; thereafter the hotel will have to live off the reputation earned from providing the guests with a satisfying stay. I am not sure the management has realised that yet.

Just spent the night at the James and was truly impressed. From the bellman to the lovely woman that checked me in, everyone was very professional and attentive. Even though the rooms are relatively standard size for NYC (which means small), the space is used very wisely and the bathroom is outstanding...loved the rain shower!!However, the glaring negative was Lauren, the world's unhappiest and most miserable bartender. Jimmy itself is a great rooftop lounge with an outstanding, friendly crowd. But Lauren was clearly unhappy to be working. She complained about how busy the bar was ----- hey, guess what, it's Saturday night, and oh by the way this is your JOB! Be happy you have one. I would think in this economy the owners of the Jimmy could find the hottest, friendliest bartenders on the planet. Lauren was neither. And everyone in the place knew it.

The James takes its status as a boutique hotel very seriously. We enjoyed the intimate conviviality with staff and concierge and the complimentary cheese and wine in the evening. The fitness center is great and so is the (very popular) rooftop bar if you can squeeze in. Dinner at the adjoining David Burke restaurant was not all it was cracked up to be, at least for us, but we understand they are still making adjustments to the service (dismal) and menu (pretty good). All in all, we enjoyed our small but ingenious room and would definitely return. Try for a high floor!

First time I've stayed lower than 40th and I'm kicking myself for not doing it sooner. Situated in Soho amongst bars and boutique shops with a bit more character than you find on 5th, but handy for subway (2 minute walk to the nearest line and then 15 minutes to 5th). Seemed a very new hotel; clean, well decorated and aircon to die for. Good quality bedding and decent double-glazing - if you've not stayed in NY be prepared for traffic horns and sirens. Floor to ceiling windows throughout including a glass wall separating the bathroom from the bedroom; remember to drop the blind if you want to avoid putting on a 'show' for the office workers in the blocks opposite.Liked the open-air bar on ground floor although a little pricey. Same goes for bar on roof but worth it considering the views. You're not going to be doing laps in the small pool but its great for cooling off. A few loungers and chairs, although space is a little on tight side - fine when I visitedthe roof during the week but packed on Saturday. Until 9 the bar's for guests but after 9 its open to the public (the pretty crowd) and numbers are restricted; being a guest doesn't mean you get priority.On the whole the staff were superb but we did have a bit of a run-in with one waiter with a bit of an attitude problem but that wasn't going to spoil our stay.I definitely recommend this for both business and pleasure; smart and stylish but not too up itself.

I would probably rate The James New York higher if I hadn't stayed at The James in Chicago before. I LOVE The James in Chicago, but the New York version didn't live up to my James expectations.The room itself was fine (very modern and cool), and the staff was awesome. The Soho location was also great. But I missed the warmth of the room design of The James in Chicago, the full-sized bottles in the minibar, the Kiehl's amenities, the amazing service. Overall, it was a good stay, but it wasn't what I expected.

Our stay at The James exceeded my expectations! We had a room on a high floor with a great view of the river. The room was clean and modern. I loved the glass wall in the bathroom. It really made the room look spacious. The staff was professional and helpful. They really made me feel special and pampered since it was my birthday. We had lunch outside in the garden and went to Jimmy's on the roof for drinks. I know nothing is perfect but this seemed as perfect as it gets. The soho neighborhood is very cool, great shopping and restaurants. I will certainly be back.

I've lived in NY for a long time, and this is the first time I've been to a bar that has a great vibe, personable bartenders, a gorgeous view, outdoor patio, and a genuinely cool crowd that isn't try too hard. The 9:00pm cut off to hotel guests only is a brilliant policy that gives guests a unique privilege, while also keeping Jimmy a best kept secret for New Yorkers in the know.
I would recommend this hotel because the staff was attentive, it was clean and affordable.Enjoy!

I stayed at the James Hotel New York these pst two days, the hotel is very nice, clean, cool looking and well staffed, need help at this hotel ask, Michael R at the door, Randolph H as well.... Need someting from teh front desk, ask Dan Marshall he and Tennile Boyd are the absolut best, let me just say this does not go for all staff, some need a little bit of learning on how to deal with answering clients. This hotel offers many emenities....or does it.... wast of time if you need a united service hotel.... the roof top is great looking but managed by some upthigt people, the restaurant has good food but is so very complicated, cant sit here at this time, cant eat there at that time..... come on this could be the greatest hotel in New York...... JUST NEEDS TO COORDINATE.... on vacation or for business,,, we all like simple. Simple answers, simple navigation in our hotel please. If you want acces make sure to bring a pad and pen otherwise.... you will get lost in what you are allowed to do!! Cynthia Hotel guest room 606 James New York July 2011
user_name:
canadiencyn
New York City, New York

review_body: The James is a relatively new and very hip hotel in the heart of SoHo. The decor and vibe is very cool and one gets the impression that this hotel is taking a few shots at the significantly smaller and older SoHo Grand, just around the corner. The Hotel almost succeeds to do it all but still needs some work. When we arrived, our promised room was not available and we were placed into a handicap accessible room on a lower floor. The room was already showing signs of some wear due to lack of attention. The views, even on the 9th floor of 17 were very good. We had a Corner King room. We utilized all the hotel had to offer in the way of several bars and a club named Jimmy. The club is definitely not for people our age. Fifty nine is about 30 years older than the very hip, well dressed crowd that was having a great time. It is worth it though for a drink at the spectacular roof bar. Note: You must be "on the list" to get into Jimmy! ASk at the front desk. Other Pros; Excellent Beds, Quite room, friendly service people from start to finish. Cons: Somewhat of a disconnect from entrance personnel to front desk staff. Front desk staff is excellent. Rooms wasn't as promised, but staff did a nice job in making it up to us.

Really cool hotel, especially the design and the different bars/food spots inside. Perfect for taking a date for the weekend. The staff was always accommodating and friendly but not annoying, a rare thing to come by and that alone would make me go back. Awesome beds.

Stayed at the James NYC for 2 nights in a queen room. This was our second stay and the James is quickly becoming our favorite when we want to stay downtown. Our queen room was quite small, but well thought out with a good size bathroom, and large windows looking out on the city. The rooftop bar / nightclub Jimmy has fantastic views but is a bit of a scene. (we skipped it this trip) Overall The James is a fun place to stay in a great location, with a friendly and helpful staff. We can't wait to return.

I have been to NY 4 times this year, and stayed in 6 different hotels (2 in single trip because moved from Business trip hotel to personal trip hotel), and I have spent well over 45 nights in hotels in 8 countries this year. I met up with friend from Canada for boy’s weekend out in NY. All in all a pretty blurry weekend. The hotel was great, about check in, and just making sure we where taken care of, at anytime of day or night. I normally do not right reviews, however, after a recent stay at the SOHO grand, which was very disappointing; on this occasion I thought it necessary. It seems the hotel has improved on many of the items that people had complained about in the past, we had no problems gaining access to Jimmy, the staff was great, and the concierge and doorman where really good. For this area of New York I would highly recommend it.

We needed to vacate our Manhattan apartment for a few days and wanted to have easy access to Tribeca restaurants. Ergo, the James.The public spaces are striking and comfortable. Lots of outdoor space (great for us: we had our dogs) and a pool and sundeck on the roof. The room itself was stylish, but small. The huge glass-walled bathroom (rain shower big enough for two) had an electric curtain for privacy. The room windows open, which is always nice. The bed was quite comfortable; I didn't love the pillows, but they offered three others, which I was too lazy to call for.Continental breakfast was included in our rate. It was prompt and quite generous, although the pastries were forgettable.Service in general was friendly and extremely competent--the requested newspaper there in the morning, extra shampoo and conditioner (excellent brand, btw) delivered to room, etc.Though the hotel is known mostly for its club scene at night, there was no noise whatsoever, although I know it was packed.Dog amenities include a full roll of disposal bags, a great can of treats, and a printed list of nearby dog "attractions."

Picked the James based on Tripadvisor reviews and downtown location. It was a lovely hotel with very helpful staff and some very nice touches. These included for guests:a) a kettle - yippee - I hate that US hotels don't usually have this as I need a cup of tea to start the day and don't was that fuss of room serviceb) fruit bowl in lobby as well as, coffee and pastries, cheese and wine and cookies at various points in the day.c) free, and easy to access, internet access in the lobby for up to an hour at a time as well as general WiFid) Newspapers and listing guides (Time Out) e) Art books and various art installations through out the hotel.f) chocolates and a turndown serviceThe room was well appointed and had excellent air con . It had just the loveliest bed - slept really well. Location was ideal for down town - it was in Soho and very close to Canal Street subway.The pool was really tiny but the view from the rooftop was great. The lobby and garden were also nicely laid out.The elevators were sometimes a bit slow as there appeared to be only two. There was an odd arrangement in getting to street level where you had to use the stairs or go to the lobby and take another lift but this was odd rather than annoying.It wasn't the cheap option but I would definitely stay there again and recommend it.

My husband and I traveled to NYC for a family event and booked a short 2-night stay at The James--a hotel I thoroughly researched and trusted would meet our expectations. Several months prior to the trip, I booked the stay through Luxurylink.com, which offered a good rate for a king bed room and breakfast in bed. To our huge disappointement--we got neither. We had traveled extensively in the past and often relied on luxurylink to book our accomodations and never encountered an issues no matter where in the world our travels took us.After a red eye flight from the west coast and numerous prior calls to The James (all indicating that we would be acommodated earlier in the morning), we walked into the hotel exhausted and, as we soon found out, out of luck. Apparently, the hotel had just booked up and we were not going to get the room until, well, "Indefinitely". In fact, nothing became available until after 1 pm, by which point we already got a quick nap in my sister's room who was kind enough to evacuate so that we could get a few hours of sleep (my sister and husband arrived a day earlier). This was a very unpleasant welcome, but considering how hotels operate in general--not overly disappointing and barring additional problems--could prove to be a decent stay. However, what unfolded next was a complete screw up of our reservation and a major blow to our experience with the hotel.After spending a very busy day in the city, we returned to our room (which we barely even saw during the day) only to find that we were given a lower category room with a queen, instead of king, size bed. To some this may not have been much of a problem, but this was extremely important and one of the main selling points of this hotel's package on luxurylink. It was quite late in the evening and I proceeded to call the reception desk only to be told that we were placed in the correct category and should only have a queen size bed. This got me fuming as I knew what I booked and had the reservation confirmation right in front of me. The staff made us go downstairs to "show proof" of our reservation and my husband reluctantly did so. In conclusion, the hotel did nothing about the wrong room as, according to them, they were all booked up anyway. After insisting for the next 30 minutes that we deserved more than just a king size room the next night, we were still left with nothing--in our tiny room and tiny bed. I will admit that they did put us up in a higher category room the next day; however, since it was only available late in the afternoon and we had a busy day, we could not enjoy it until quite late in the evening. The room; however, was nice, but did not make up for the unpleasant welcome or all the frustration of the night before. After returning home, I took another look at our booking and noticed that we never received or were even asked about the breakfasts in bed which we were supposed to get on the two mornings we were there. Apparently, that--just like the kind size bed--was magically disappeared from the reservation. This realization, along with the fact that The James has been completely unresponsive to our issues surrounding our stay, is why I would never want to return or recommend this hotel to others. Had it not been for these gross errors and neglect in customer service, I would consider this a good place to stay. The hotel does have a nice location if you want to walk around SoHo and some interesting quirks like the roof pool, very modern design, etc.

The hotel is nicely laid out with pool and contemporary furnishings and staff are more friendly than the other top-end hotels in Soho area we have stayed at such as Mercer and Thompson. However they made 3 pretty fundamnental mistakes - they tried to overcharge me $150 for the room, then blaming it on 'computer glitch', they were unable to honour the 2pm check-in time despite the fact i phoned ahead to make sure as my wife was coming in from transatlantic flight and finally they were unable to locate my stored luggage for ages due to a mishap. Manager extended the minimum of aplologies when i pointed these issues out.
The rudest hotel manager I have ever met in any hotel anywhere. Arrogant, patronising and aggressive.

I stayed here twice on two consecutive Mondays. The hotel itself is very well designed, the rooms are comfortable, and the staff is amazing. So, so nice. Like, you're not even in NYC nice. And I actually live in NYC so I don't automatically assume everyone in NYC is rude. Chris, who greets you when you first enter, is the nicest person I have ever met in the service industry. The only drawback to this place was that their systems didn't seem quite in order. For instance, when I arrived in my room, the folder containing the hotel info, including the room service menu (which is what I was looking for), was empty. I called the front desk, who very nicely explained the info was in the folder. When I told them it was empty, they apologized and sent up a new folio. Well, the first guy who came brought me a menu for the restaurant, which was not the same as room service, but the second guy got it right. Communication seemed to be a little off.Another small thing: The breakfast menu that you hang on the door was waiting for me on the bed, except it was already filled out, and by another room! Such a small thing - I just ordered a new one - but so, so strange to me how this could have happened. Someone obviously not paying a lot of attention. When breakfast came the next morning, they had forgotten milk for my coffee. I'm not the kind of person who gets upset about stuff like that, but I note it. I just called and asked for milk - they were super nice and apologetic. I also asked for water, but was only brought milk. No big deal, but again, it seems like such a small thing could be prevented by a little more attention to detail, actually checking the tray before it leaves the kitchen. I didn't get to check out the roofbar because they were having a private party - both times. Kind of a disappointment.I really hope they get these details straightened out, because then it would be a perfect hotel. The second time I stayed with my dog, and they were so sweet to her. She got a little gift bag with doggy treats. (Although, somewhat in keeping with the other small overlooked details, there was a dog bed in the room but no dog bowl, so she drank out of a glass. I didn't feel like calling the desk yet again for something).I also used the valet parking which was very easy and convenient. The food at the restaurant and the room service food was just ok. The service at the restaurant was a little lackluster - the waiters spent as much time talking to each other as they did waiting on the tables, and I had to stand up and wave a few times to get things. But they were nice enough. Just not very attentive. I sat in the outdoor garden area on my first visit.One more thing: I hope the management will allow dogs into the outdoor garden area of the restaurants, because it was hard for me to find a place to eat with dog in tow.
user_name:
jessls87
New York City, New York

review_body: Let me start by saying, I will certainly stay here again!! The hotel is beautiful, and the rooms are even better. I had a Corner King room on the 15th floor with great views south and west. The bathroom was beautiful, with a large shower and an oversized rainfall shower and outfitted with high end fixtures. It featured a glass wall looking into the bedroom with an electronic art shade. The bed was soft and luxurious with natural, organic fabrics. The location is also a few blocks away from several subway stations as well as the happening area of Soho.The service I received was as good, if not better than many other 5 star hotels I have stayed. Dan, from the front desk, was awesome! He arranged dinner reservations, shared his knowledge of theatre options, and always called me by name. The continental breakfast is limited, but nice and convenient. The wine and cheese service in the early evenings is also a nice amenity for the hotel. The rooftop Pool and bar is quite popular with awesome views of the city. Also, the David Burke Kitchen in the cellar of the hotel is incredible. It makes for a convenient and excellent meal while in NYC.

My husband and I spent a Saturday night at the James, and were generally satisfied, despite the tiny rooms and crowded corner location. The valet and lobby staff were great - more than nice and attentive. However, we had a horrendous experience with the door staff at the rooftop bar, "Jimmy" that evening. We arrived at the door on a rainy evening at about 10pm, and there was absolutely NO ONE on line. However, the doorman not only refused us entry, but was inappropriate, condescending and rude to us. I am an adult and a mother who simply wanted to see the bar/view and have a post-dinner drink, and I was treated like garbage by this person. When I reported our experience to the hotel staff in the lobby, the staff and manager were apologetic, understanding and accommodating. However, the bad taste left by the doorman at the bar - and the silliness of keeping paying, adult guests out of a half-empty bar - left a bad taste in my mouth about the hotel.

having been a happy, frequent guest at the james in chicago i was really looking forward to trying the james hotel in new york. to say it was a disappointment would be kind.horrible (non existent) public spaces, poor customer service and tiny rooms. the furnishings in the lobby, bar etc. are totally unsuitable for commercial use and were all looking tired and beat up, despite the newness of the hotel. yet another hotel that has been designed to look good in travel magazines/online but is uncomfortable and non ergonomic to actually stay in. the bell staffs main function seemed to be guards/bouncers and there was never a friendly greeting from them. they seemed to have been hired for their funky haircuts rather than their customer service skills. in fact that seems to be the whole problem with these hotel, a sad attempt at "cool" with not even a sad attempt at hospitality. the closest thing i saw to any attempt at hospitality was a couple of cheap bottles of wine and some picked over cheese in the "lobby", if a desk and a few chairs stuck in the corner can constitute a lobby.david burkes restaurant was ok but it and the hotel bars all seemed to be more interested in catering to outside guests than making the hotels guests feel comfortable/important and they didn't feel like they were even part of the hotel.all in all it felt like a stay at an apartment building, not a stay at a hotel. despite its newness the james new york needs a complete overhaul, the staff and management need to learn how to make a guest feel welcome and the layout/design needs a major rethink. i would say style over substance but there wasn't enough style for that saying to be appropriate.

we booked a room here through the hotels website, paid in advance (with a no refund if canceled clause) in order to get a corner room at a decent price. however we never received a corner room so i risked loosing $1700 if my plans changed but i never got the corner room. great deal for the hotel, not for me.the front desk staff were nice and our room was ok but very small, that's about the best i can say about the james ny. i thought the layout of the hotel was awful, virtually no common areas and totally disjointed. if i didn't know better i say they had tried to fit a hotel into a totally unworkable space. who ever designed the layout seems to have no idea how to create functional public space, cool elements here and there but no "flow".to be frank we felt like interlopers and to be honest by the end of our stay i was sick of continually being asked "where are you going?" (in an accusational tone) every time we entered the hotel from the street or looked for a place to get a drink at jimmys. it felt as if the whole place was being run for guests of the restaurant and bars, not for the guests of the hotel.the outdoor lounge area next to jimmys bar was not furnished up to par, with stained and cigarette burned couches and when we asked for a drink there we were told the staff at jimmy bar (20 feet away) couldn't serve us there because it was hotel property???? i've stayed at many of the neighboring hotels in the past, none of which is great but at least at the mercer and the soho grand the doormen, bar/restaurant staff are friendly and remember you after a day or two. all in all the restaurant and bar seem at odds with the hotel rather than part of it and the whole place has no cohesion. we love the james hotel in chicago but would not return to the james new york.

So I really can't say any negatives about this great HO-tel. I had a great time hear visiting from Miami. The boys are cute in new York and the girls are naughty. So this is what trendy and new York is about. The staff was very kind. Loved ordering room service. Jimmy the rooftop bar was raunchy. Nice views from the gym. My one complaint is the hotel should get a designer who can dress the staff like they live in the new millennium.

The Guest Services staff at the The James do a great job, the best we've experienced in New York City ( as a reference point, we've stayed at a number of hotels in Soho in the past including the Mercer). They strike a perfect balance between friendly/informal and efficient/knowledgeable - the restaurant recommendations we received from Matt were particularly good.Views from the rooftop bar are real plus, although on one of the four nights we visited it was out of bounds due to a private hire. I assume that there's a limit on the number of private bookings that would be taken as from a hotel resident perspective it would be annoying if it was a frequent occurrence. We really enjoyed our stay and would be very happy to return.

I almost did not write this review. We arrived early on a friday, well before check in time. We left our bags downstairs and grabbed lunch, walked around. At 1:30 i recieve a call saying the room was ready. We get back to the hotel at approx 2:45. Gave our baggage claim tickets to the bellhop downstairs and went to the lobby. Room was not ready. We then waited another hour till we got our room. The room was dusty with lint bits all over the floor. A spare cot was in there (even though it was a king corner studio, the room was quite small) which we had to get them to take out. After 4 pm, we still did not have our bags. The person who we gave the tickets to was no longer there. The bellhop said that he was backed up. I went downstairs to retrieve the bags. I had to help the desk manager sort through the pile of luggage to find my bags. To their credit, they were apologetic and did put some chocolate and wine (cheap) on our bed that night before we got in. I was going to let bygones be bygones, but other another couple from the hotel shared a car back to laguardia and we got to talking. their issues were regarding poor housekeeping service. guess what? they got the same chocolate and cheap wine! lastly, i received an email stating some other guest lost their luggage and they were wondering if we had "found an extra piece of luggage." overall, the people were generally nice but not good at running a hotel. or perhaps they didn't have enough people. or both.on the plus side. location is great and the bed was comfortable.won't go back.

My wife and I have stayed for 3 night in this new hotel in Soho. We were put on a marvelous corner loft so we had an amazing view of the city and the river. They dont have windows, they have top-to-bottom glasses that makes you feel part of the city itself. Bathroom also is amazing with a glass-wall. We were nicely treated always, enjoyed good breakfast at David Burkes kitchen and were delighted by the view from the rooftop, where a bar called Jimmy is packed every single day. If you enjoy walking around at the coolest neighborhoods like Greenwich, West Village, and Soho, then this is your place.
user_name:
Rafael C
Rio de Janeiro, RJ

review_body: We stayed at The James for 3 nights from May 19, 2011. We told the hotel we would be arriving at approximately 3:30. Our flight was delayed so we didn't arrive at the hotel until after 4:00. Check-in time was 2:00. Our room wasn't ready and we had to wait approx 75 minutes before our room was ready. The receptionist suggested we have dinner downstairs while we waited (at 4:00???).The room itself is nicely appointed -- wood floors (nice for cleanliness) and bottles of complimentary water.On the rooftop is a very "sceney" bar called Jimmy. LIke something out of Entourage -- beautiful people with cocktails making out and swanning around a teensy weensy pool. Much of the hotel is geared around this vibe -- house music, a bit too cool...For context, my fave hotel that I've stayed at in NYC is the Library Hotel. I'll return there before The James.

Stayed in hotel for three days due to a business trip in your York and had a very nice time. The personnel is very cooperative and friendly, rooms are clear with big tv sets and nice view. Free wifi also provided.Hotel location is a must as you can explore the whole soho area on foot. Definitely recommend David burker kitchen restaurant.

You know, if you want a great kind of getaway but stay withing New York, what is now referred to annoyingly as a "staycation", you could not do better than The James. Why? well, I do not think that it is the greatest location despite being on the two different subway lines, but you are very much in New York, on the edge of SoHo. I adore the lobby and the warm reception although the over thinking of the uniforms is far too much effort to try to have "style". The art books also add the usual effort but it is the homegrown art work, some of bad, some of it good, that lends real city credentials to this hotel. A galpal came into town and I wanted to not crowd my apartment. The room was wonderful with floor to celing wondows that look over the entrance to the Holland Tunnel. I know it may sound a bit odd, but never have so may cars going away, been so relaxing. Yes the rooms are perhaps over-designed, including a clear bathroom which one can push a button to make a shade come down. It can be sexy, ( or frankly not) but here it is not too onnoxious. Is it a turn on to have friends see you on the loo? The shower is out of control with pressure- so you are getting your hair wet. The seating area was nice and it although the halls felt corporate, the fact that there was local talent on the walls made up for the harsh lighting. The restaurants are fantastic, elevating this hotel to a great spot to hunker back for a weekend, read and get a little work done and relax without leaving. I cannot speak enough about the service and on top of it all they are. I travel a lot and wish that I could get the level of service, minus the odd outfits everywhere I go. Now, if the hoards of people begin to come to Jimmy or the Treehouse, well, then the effect could be out thewindow. Let's hope not.....
user_name:
Fattycrab
New York City, New York

review_body: My wife and I initially stayed at the James back in 2010 and there were some aspects of our stay that didn't go as planned and I posted a frustrated review. It was a period of management turnover, and shortly thereafter the new general manager was thoughtful enough to reach out to me and invite us back to give things a second chance.We came back recently, I have to say, they really blew me away with the level of attention and execution. The hotel looks great, the staff is super attentive and the rooms are fantastic (though that has always been the case). Every person we interacted with was incredibly welcoming and it is clear that folks are now enjoying themselves there. As a result, the experience for the guests is very postiive. I can't say enough about the styling of the room that we stayed in as well as the hotel as a whole. We will definitely be returning to The James.
user_name:
jumpset45
New York City, New York

review_body: My husband and I wanted to take a couple of days off to unwind from our busy work schedules. We booked our stay at The James as we wanted to experience the location compared to the upper eastside, where we usually stay. Upon our arrival at 2pm (hotel's check in time) we were told that our room wasn't cleaned yet so they would call our cell and let us know when it was done. We were assured it wouldn't be too long. So we took a walk in to Soho and went shopping. It was about 2 hours and we still hadn't heard back from the hotel so we went for a quick bite and came back to the hotel to be informed that the room still wasn't ready. The staff wasn't too surprised at this but we mentioned we had dinner reservations and need to shower and change and we had already been waiting to check in for 3 hrs. They gave us another room that had been cleaned and we checked in. I don't understand how check out is at 2pm and check in is at 2pm. This really doesn't work well for the incoming guests and is extremely frustrating to have to wait that long to get into your room as promised. Our room was great as far as the view and the bed was so comfortable. It was a bit dirty on the floor and rug and it seemed that the cleaning staff had missed a lot. The next dayy it was cleaned much better.The Jimmy upstairs is really nice except they only had one selection pinto grios and f this was so over priced and the quality was extremely poor. Actually, I didn't even finish it. We worked out in the gym and the equipment was great and with a great view! The hotel is definitely in a great location for many resturants and we walked over to Hudson River Park which I would recommend as it was heaven just sitting there looking over at Jersey. So peaceful!!! We enjoyed our stay there but feel they need to work out their check in issues as well as making sure that the cleaning staff does a better job. The staff was helpful and the in room breakfast was outstanding!!!

The hotel had only been open a few weeks before I arrived (mid Oct). I was really looking forward to it as I´m a big fan of their excellent hotel in Chicago.As the hotel was very new none of the taxi drivers knew where it was. So keep the address  handy so they can type it in to their Sat Navs. We were lucky to find the hotel as there was no name above the entrance and there were no doormen. (A name was put up while I was there)  There are actually 2 reception areas, one at the entrance, and the main one on the first floor.  (Where you check in)At check we were offered a corner room. If you can, these are the rooms to get as the views are stunning.The restaurant was not open which was a disappointment as the restaurant at the James in Chicago is first class. Also there was no bar or any alcohol available to purchase (no license) this was bizarre for a luxury hotel.  The nearest the staff could offer was a deli on the corner which delivered, but you had to eat in your hotel room as there was no dining area. Eating a $8 wrap in your room is something you´d do in a $20 a night backpackers hostel. Not in a $250+ a night boutique hotel.For breakfast there was complimentary coffee and pastries and in the afternoon cheese and (rather average) wine.There was no concierge, which again in a luxury hotel is something you would expect. Though the staff had a list of nearby restaurant this isn´t the same as having a dedicated concierge who has expert knowledge of bars and restaurants etc.I asked one of the staff to make a brunch reservation in one of the hottest restaurants in town. I was horrified when I got to the restaurant and they had no record of the reservation.  This could have been the fault of the restaurant and not of the hotel staff. In the end it wasn´t a problem as I got a table after only a 5 min wait.I wanted to know how much a shuttle was to JFK so I asked the front desk staff in the morning, they did not know, I was a surprised by this as I thought it a fairly standard question. However, they promised to look into it and have an answer later in the day. When I returned later in the day the staff had changed and had not left any details with their colleagues so it was a case of back to square one. This was very frustrating.I discovered by chance there was an excellent roof top gym when I saw a fellow guest in gym clothes. I was not told about the gym at check in nor were there any signs. Again, I thought this to be a real oversight.One night it was raining and the hotel had run out off complimentary umbrellas. I found this unbelievable especially considering the hotel could not have been more than 20% full. Rain is not uncommon in New York, and I was stunned that they only had about 4 or 5 for a hotel that has so many rooms.  Surely they could have gone to a local store and bought a few.The overall standard of the room was excellent. The staff were young (all under 30) and naturally had only been there for a matter of weeks but were very friendly and attentive.The lifts at times were painfully slow to arrive. There are only 2, which in a hotel with around 20 floors doesn´t seem to be enough. I would hate to see it when the hotel is 100% full.As it was mid Oct the rooftop bar wasn´t open yet. This was a shame as on their web the views looked fantastic.Overall I had a positive experience. It is is a great hotel and centrally located. I did come away with the feeling that it was very much a work in progress, the hotel wasn´t finished,  there were tradesmen working the whole time I was there (though they didn´t cause too much noise or inconvenience)

Perfect location, next to 3 metro and 3 train lines. Walking distance to bars, galleries and boutiques of Soho and not far on foot from Little Italy and Chinatown. The most friendly and helpful stuff I've ever met, ready to give information as real New Yorkers - not just employees (special thanks to Leslie).Beautiful minimal decor, nice view, great room decoration, loved the chocolates and fresh water every day.Great gourmet restaurant, thus expensive.
Cool place to stay close to LES, Soho etc. Walking distance to nice restaurants and bars, Outstanding roof top bar!

This hotel is beautiful and the staff is BEYOND helpful, they really go the extra mile to make your stay special. The only problem is the room we had was on a corner, and the curtains did not completely close.. making sleeping in quite difficult. The bar Jimmy is super cute as well!!! PS the room service burger and fries are amazing

We stayed at The James for five nights. The rooms were well equipped, not necessarily spacious but fine for New York. The bed was very comfortable, and the chocolate for both of us in the evening was a nice touch. We stayed on the fifth floor and were initially a little worried that we might hear some street noise - we needn't have worried as we didn't hear much at all from outside.There are quite a few bars and restaurants downstairs, and a convenience store just across the road. There's also a subway stop literally around the corner, and a stop on another line about ten minutes walk away.Like some other reviewers, we noticed that wine and cheese is served around 5 in the evening, but unfortunately only on our last evening. Unlike some other hotels I researched, the wifi is completely free and works well. The only slight downside is that you need to revalidate the wifi every 12 hours, although it's not a big deal.Perhaps the only fault we could find was the size of the gym. Whilst we realise space is at a premium in New York, when we went to use the gym all five or so machines were in use. Probably if we went at a less busy time of the day (we tried to use the gym at around 8 am) we would have been ok, but more fitness machines (including upright bikes, for which there were none) might help.FInally, the hotel had a business centre of sorts in the lobby, which had a printer we could use for free - great for printing boarding passes. Overall though, very hard to fault and we had a great time in New York and at the James. We wouldn't hesitate to visit again.

We booked into the James for two nights, and extended it to four nights - BECAUSE WE LOVED IT. The staff were wonderful! From the moment I called to book it, to the moment we checked out, we were treated like FAMILY. I have traveled a lot, all over the world, and NEVER had such a great hotel experience in my entire life! The beds are so cosy, the room service was so good, and the views from the room were fab. BOOK IT!!!!!
user_name:
LaraMascaraNYC
New York City, New York

review_body: I just returned from an amazing trip to NY and a perfect stay at The James! Do yourself a favour and book this hotel immediately! The doormen, lobby, receptionists, rooms, turn down service, rooftop pool/deck/bar. Everything about it is fantastic. New to the area?
