Ask CHRIS or GIOVANNI (doormen) for ANYTHING and they will have the answer. They truly made my stay amazing and I can't thank them enough. Stay at The James...thank me later!

We usually stay in Midtown, but decided to stay in Soho after reading about The James. The location is perfect, right next to the Canal St. subway station, which gets you anywhere, close to great restaurants, shopping and Soho nightlife. The rooms are small, which you expect in NYC, but nicely appointed. However, the best reason to stay at The James is the staff. Every single employee we encountered went out of their way to attend to our needs. They are so genuinely nice that you forget to tip them! Leslie W. at the desk went out of her way to help my daughter and I find a bar yoga class at Physique 57, and another woman working at the front desk sent cookies up to our room when my daughter was sad that we got back too late the night before to grab some (they set out food all day long). The doormen were awesome... Everyone was so great that when we left I almost thought they would miss us! If you are weighing different hotel options, I'd give the James special consideration, especially if you prefer Soho to the more touristy options. It truly felt like a home away from home.

We stayed at the James Hotel in New York and loved it. The staff was super friendly (girls at the concierge desk, Micheal the bellhop, etc.), the rooms were quite spacious considering NYC, and the view was great. The hotel offered us a cot (free of charge), coffee and danish in the morning, wine and cheese late afternoon, complimentary wi-fi and mac computers, filtered water, chocolate at our bedside in the evening, the list goes on.Highly recommend this hotel. Great location and walking distance to good restaurants and shops.

Recently had the pleasure of spending a few nights at The James Hotel in Soho. I spend a lot of nights in hotels every year, so have a good basis for comparison. The room was spacious and clean, with a great view. Temperature control was excellent, and the room was very quiet. The location is great, 1 block from the subway and surrounded by great restaurants and all kinds of shopping. Great restaurant associated with the hotel, good food and a nice bar too.I will be back again.

I rarely write reviews but found that I must in this case. I run national sales so am always on the road and essentially live out of hotels. In a previous career I worked with luxury properties running wine programs so am familiar with the demands and also various levels of service, programs etc. I recently stayed at the James Hotel and it was one of my most favorable stays at any hotel especially in NYC. I was incredibly impressed by the room size (this is much more roomie in comparison to the normal mini nyc rooms), the service, the quality of products (ie wine program, esoteric mini bar offerings, shampoo/conditioner being organic, paraben, sulfate free etc). Each night guests are provided chocolate truffles and warm chocolate cookies as an added nice touch. The service is also fantastic in a genuine way. Its amazing that the hotel offers so many amazing perks yet still at a reasonable rate for the NYC market! I really cant wait to return....they even have a fantastic roof top bar that gives you the true NYC nightlife feel. Location is in the heart of SOHO so walking distance to everything you could possibly need including shopping, great restaurants etc.

I had never heard of The James Hotel but heard from a friend that is was new so figured I would give it a try. Glad that I did. I couldn't find anything that I didn't like about this place. Having been fooled by Trip Advisor reviews in the past, I decided to write something because of a rare possitive experience in NYC. It is so incredibly unique, you may think you are somewhere else; from the architecture to the furnishings in the rooms to the multi-tiered outdoor areas that are a couple of stories above street level. Bringing the family in April and can't wait to use the patio areas in spring. FANASTIC EXPERIENCE!

Stay at The James! The hotel was in a fantastic area - right in the heart of Soho but on a quiet corner, with great convenience to all the best shopping, restaurants, bars, etc. Every single person that works at the James is committed to making you feel at home! We were only there for one night, but they were so accommodating and friendly! The customer service was just great - top notch - I can't say enough about it! And the room was pretty big (we were in a corner suite), and had a fantastic view of the city. We loved the modern, sleek, minimalist decor. The bed was one of the most comfortable beds I have ever slept in! And the rooftop bar, Jimmy - you HAVE to check it out! Drinks are pricey but VERY unique, and the view at sunset is unbelievable! We cannot wait to go back - The James has become our go-to hotel in NYC!

Loved our actual stay at The James. Our go-to hotel in NYC is the Gansevoort, but thought we'd try the new James that we read was opening. We booked before the hotel even opened, slightly nervous that there would be kinks and growing pains when we arrived. We were pleasantly surprised that the stay was fairly seamless. Here's our take:PROS: - We were impressed before we arrived. I received a call from the concierge a few days before our arrival asking if we had any special requests. We've stayed at various Four Seasons and Amans in more service-oriented locales than NYC and have never gotten such a call. We were equally pleased after we arrived. - Great location. - Hotel was modern and chic, minimalist decor, cool artwork. - The front desk staff was enthusiastic, friendly, and customer service oriented. We arrived on an early morning flight and our room was not ready. They told us they would prepare one right away. We went for breakfast and, by the time we got back an hour later, we were able to check in. Great first impression. - The room was nice. Smallish, but not bad for NYC. Cute modern decor; desk area where I was able to comfortably do some work. Bathroom was nice, has a cool glass wall so you can see into the room and out the window, but you can choose to close the shade. - Free wifi, which is always a plus! (It's such a racket when hotels charge you for wifi, given how much you pay for the room.) - Every evening, the hotel offered complimentary wine and cheese in the lobby at around 5 pm, which was a really nice touch. One evening, we enjoyed a glass of wine while surfing the net in their business center looking for a bar we wanted to check out. We stopped by on a second evening (we stayed for 5 nights), but the set up wasn't ready (maybe evidence of some growing pains here). - Door guys were cheery and enthusiastically greeted us every time we walked in. Each night, they asked if we wanted to be escorted up to the rooftop bar to avoid any lines. Very nice.CONS: - The reservations department is awful. You can't ever get through on the phone. The hold recording tells you that if you input your number, someone will call you back when it's your turn in the queue. I did that a couple of time, but no one ever called me back. It seems like they outsource it and that the calls don't go directly to the hotel. - The walls of the rooms are very thin. I tried to take a nap one day and could hear the man next door on a business call that lasted nearly an hour. - Also, one evening we tried to go up to the rooftop bar, but were told it was closed for a private event, which was disappointing. - Otherwise, we had no real complaints about the hotel. We thoroughly enjoyed it and would have given the hotel 5 stars, particularly on service, in this review, if not for the follow up service (or lack thereof) we received. Because we were one of the early guests staying at the James during the first months after its opening in the fall of 2010, we were offered a free night if we came back within a certain timeframe at the beginning of 2011. We decided to go back to NYC, so I called the hotel attempting to book a reservation and redeem the offer for the one-night stay. Well, turns out that's not such an easy thing to do. I called on separate occasions and have not been able to get anyone to help me. I was told that the person I needed to speak with is someone in the general manager's office. Despite calling twice and leaving her a message, I've gotten no response from her or anyone. Apparently, the James was not interested in honoring what seemed to be a very cool and generous offer it made to its guests. It's really a shame because our experience was fairly positive and we would have been return guests (in fact, as mentioned, I tried to book another reservation!). Unfortunately, this subsequent experience really soured our opinion of the hotel. Maybe back to the Gansevoort it is for us.

The first time we stayed at The James was last year during their soft-opening It was my birthday and they had champagne and fresh baked cookies waiting for us in our room! To make it even better, they gave us a very late check-out and a free voucher to return once they had all their facilities up and running. So we had recently stayed again and it was just as great as before.. the staff is incredibly friendly and helpful. Rooms are cozy - a bit on the smaller side compared to hotels outside NYC (but reasonable by NYC standards) and nicely decorated. We got a very late check-out again at 4pm again. This time, we tried their restaurant - very tasty. And bc it was difficult to get a taxi, the hotel service dropped us off to our rental car agency without our asking.We've encountered no problems at The James yet even if we would have, we're confident that any problems would be immediately corrected by their staff.. they're exceptional. We've been to several hotels in NYC and The James is by far, our favorite place to stay.

I have stayed at The James Hotel in New York 3 times (for work and pleasure) since it opened, and have loved it each time. The hotel is located in a wonderful spot in Soho close to great shopping and fun nightlife (and subway stations). The hotel is bright, airy, modern, and clean and each hotel room has floor to ceiling windows with views of the surrounding neighborhood. The "Jimmy" bar on the top floor of the hotel is a popular place to grab a cocktail and check out the amazing night view of the city. Even though the hotel itself is wonderful, the most memorable part of each of my stays has been the exceptional service and the genuine friendliness of the staff. I cannot stress enough how the staff at The James has made each one of my trips to New York easy, enjoyable, and wonderful. A++.

I stayed at The James not knowing that it was still "a work in progress". The lift to the reception wasn't working, the restaurant wasn't working, and most of the other services were not working as well. To make matters worse, one of my shirts was stolen (or misplaced) by housekeeping and my dry cleaning went missing for a day and did not show up until minutes before I left for the airport. As a consolation, the manager sent me a letter giving me a free night at the hotel which was a nice gesture, but he put an unrealistic deadline to take the offer. I live outside of the country and travel to New York frequently, but could not make it in time for the deadline.I am planning to travel again to New York and decided to give The James another chance since the first experience may have been due to a new inexperienced staff. I called reservations and asked to speak to the person noted in the letter (as instructed in the letter). I was told that he no longer worked there and that I should speak to Jennifer. Jennifer did not answer the telephone, so I found out her email address and emailed her the request and explained that I could not make it before March 31 but was wondering if they could make an exception due to the horrific experience the first time and since I was planning on spending another 4 nights at the hotel (not just taking advantage of one free night). No answer. So I decided to call again to The James and was put in contact with the office manager. I reminded her that I sent her an email and she acknowledged that she received it but for whatever reason did not respond to it (a bad sign already that things have not changed at The James). She then told me that they cannot make exceptions because if they made an exception for me, then they would have to make exceptions for all of their other customers (what is this...the Soviet Union?). After some prodding, she then said that she might be able to give me a discount on the room. However, the discount she gave me was still comparable to the prices at the Trump Soho which just opened and is a 5 star hotel! When I pointed this out to her and explained that if they would honor their letter, they would still end up ahead because I would be staying another 4 nights, she still dug in her heels and wouldn't budge. I know things are tight for hotels, but given the first bad impression I had for the hotel, this really took the cake! It's a pity because they hotel could be one of the most trendy hotels in the area, but I'm afraid that their attitude (or lack of customer service) is going to make guests flee to other hotels. It's just not worth the price...you have to climb stairs and take a lift to the cramped lobby and the rooms are even smaller. The only way for this hotel to make it in a competitive city like New York is to have outstanding, friendly service. In spite of the horrible first experience at the hotel, I was willing to give it a second chance. But why put up with unfriendly and a non-flexible attitude? Maybe the office manager was following orders, but sometimes common sense should prevail. As a result, they lost my business now and in the future and I happily made a reservation down the street at the Trump Soho. It looks like a much nicer hotel and the prices are about the same, so I will give it a try.

I am not sure if there has been a staff changeover or not from what other reviewers have mentioned, however we found the staff to be excellent - some of the most welcoming and helpful we have ever experienced. We stayed 3 nights and did not encounter anything but exceptional service. We found the location to be excellent - close to fine dining such as Nobu and Locanda Verde and great shopping. The bed and pillows were some of the most comfortable we have experienced and we are seasoned travellers. We had a corner room which while small (not by NYC standards) - it was well equipped with excellent bathroom products, heated floors and great blackout blinds. Jimmy, the rooftop bar is a definite must for its fantastic views and hip atmosphere. I would not hesitate to recommend and visit this hotel again.

I love the James in Chicago and was excited when one opened in New York. My wife and I stayed there recently and had an ok experience . The hotel was still being completed, the restaurant remained unopened and we had to hold our opinion because so much was unfinished. Clearly not worth the price we paid for the room, but the General Manager at the time, gave us a letter for a complimentary stay any day through March. When I called to book a room on Monday, I was passed from person to person and finally told that they would check and get me a confirmation about my selected date later that day. Four days went by with no response, so I called back and was finally told that there was no availability on the date in question. Plenty of rooms available at rack rates, just none available for their comp letter. Of course it was subject to availability, but that meant, I was told, not availability of the hotel, but availability of rooms suitable for fulfilling their comp letter obligations. This struck me as total BS. I was then told that the general manager and at least one other position has turned over / they've been fired in the last few days. The revenue manager (who makes these decisions) could only be reached by email because she only owns a cell phone and didn't have a hotel number. (Absurd, and not believable.)It seems the management of the hotel has lost sight of how to keep RETURN CUSTOMERS happy and the organization generally, in New York, is in a state of chaos.
user_name:
jumpset45
New York City, New York

review_body: Once past the "interesting" bunker-like exterior, you'll find a staff that is sincerely grateful to serve, and a hotel interior that is equal parts soho gallery and cozy lounge. The lobby is as inviting as any other, and the rooms convey lots of light and warmth (hardwood floors and floor to ceiling windows make all the difference), materials are first rate and overall design is comfortably understated. Did I mention it was one of the most comfortable hotel beds I’ve ever slept in? Negatives? Almost too small to mention: reservations process was not without its trouble, and although the staff is extra friendly, there seems to be no dedicated concierge. Given that the hotel has an art curator and focused on local artists (loved QWERTY 5, an art piece at ground floor), we found it curious that no one on staff we spoke to had heard of MoMA PS1 (a must for art lovers) or could help with directions.But, trust me, if you’re looking for a fabulous location, soul-comforting design, and a staff that charms from the onset, you’d be hard-pressed to do better than the James.

I travel to NYC at least every other week for my job. Since last September I have been staying at the James every trip. It is a beautiful building at a great location. You can easily access SOHO, TriBeCA, the Financial District, etc. The service is excellent. I have been impressed how enthusiastic the staff if (bellmen, front desk, cleaning staff, etc). The gym has good equipment and a great view.The basic rooms are reasonably sized for NYC hotel room and decorated well. There is a small table which is adequate for doing work, but the phone is across the room so difficult to make calls from the table. So many more good things about the hotel as well: free Wifi, free wine and cheese in the evenings, the iMacs and printers available for use in the lobby, etc. The James has become my home away from home and I highly recommend it.

Recently I stayed at the James with my husband, who was in NYC on business. I chose the "average" rating for this hotel as it has many positive attributes relative to the average hotel; however, I would rate it "poor" relative to hotels in this price range...The hotel has a number of pros, including the location (right between Soho and Tribeca), the quality/design features of the rooms, the consistently friendly and cheerful nature of the staff members, the high-quality roof-top bar, the nice gym, the free wireless, and the free food and drinks available in the lobby.However, the cons were much more problematic than I would expect for a hotel in this price range. First, they lost all of my husband's belongings for a short period (in brief, he was told to leave his belongings in his room before leaving for work, then I would arrive later in the day, collect his things, and move to an upgraded room; when I arrived, his belongings had been removed from his original room, unbeknownst to the guest services staff, and they were unable to locate them for perhaps half an hour (who knows where they were??)). Second, on my first day at the hotel, I left our room at 10am, put on the "housekeeping please" sign, and returned at 2pm only to find the room uncleaned. I called guest services and asked them to arrange for the cleaning. I complained again at 4pm (after hanging out in the lobby for longer than I would have liked), and the room cleaning wasn't completed until 5pm. Third, after 9pm hotel guests can't access the roof-top bar from inside the hotel but instead have to walk around outside and enter with everyone else. Fourth, my husband had some sort of allergic reaction (rash) to their "hypoallergenic" lotion. And finally, there were several instances when my key card didn't work on our room door, and I had to go back down to the lobby to get it reset. In sum, there were some really nice features to this hotel, but for a hotel of this caliber (and price), there were too many problems to deal with. This is a relatively new hotel, and there are clearly more kinks that need to be worked out. I wouldn't stay there again, as the irritations associated with our stay in many ways outweighed the benefits.

Positives: Great Building, Artwork, uniforms, lobby, complimentary snacks, wine, friendly staff and Jimmy is a cool and trendy bar on the roof. Issue/Complaint: Simply way to many issues on a daily basis. Wrong room given, upgrading hassles, lost personal belonging for a couple of hours, room cleaning asked for early (10am) and finally being done at 5pm, being asked to leave hotel and walk around block to enter Jimmy which is within the same building! Finally, the products in the room are not for sensitive skin. I used the body lotion and 5 mins later broke out in a beet red rash for 3 hours. Be careful! I have really wanted to love this place but having stayed here for 7 days, I have to report the truth to help the community. To The James: You have enormous potential. You have perfected the veneer, move your focus onto making the team more effective. Tweaking not firing!

I am very particular when it comes to my hotel accommodations, I have stayed at many NY hotels in search of my go to destination. I am very happy that the James has won me over! Great SOHO location, well designed rooms, the BEST rooftop pool in NY, great bar scene and some innovative cocktails, friendly service, lobby wine and coffee, complimentary pedicab and most importantly great service! I am excited for the restaurant to open to complete their offering.

The James was a very cool new hotel in SoHo. I got a great deal on my room (Corner King Studio) so that was why I chose it over the Trump. The staff was phenomenal (shout out to the doorman Christopher). Everything from the lobby to the room was clean, modern, and trendy. I knew the restaurant wasn't going to be open until February so I planned accordingly. Didn't get a chance to hit up the Jimmy (rooftop bar), but I heard it was a hot spot. I was overall very impressed with the hotel. It is definitely better than The James Chicago.

Although we live in NY, we felt a little stay-cation for the three day week-end would be better than the cost and travel time for a caribbean retreat. And it was.The requirements were five-star, in a desirable location, quiet inside, and pet friendly.We booked the king studio and got an upgrade. Parking was easy (no meters), and cabs were easy to come by for trips after we parked the car. Every single staff member was helpful and friendly. And, everyone was over the top happy with our little terrier. Each and every staff member seemed naturally pleasant. Nothing put on. True winning personalities with the door men, reception and check-in staff, and the bar crew (especially Nathalie - the manager) were what we wanted. Genuine, cool, easy-going, yet interested in providing top-notch service. I felt that every dollar was well-spent here.The bar is a place that I wouldn't leave if I didn't have to do so. The drinks were inventive, and tasty. I do not know of too many spots that have Nicaraguan rum. The views from the bar are better than going to the top of the Empire State Building. Get out of the line, get up the elevator to this sky top bar, and have a drink while you soak in the views of river to river, as well as Empire Bldg lit up and the quickly rising Freedom Tower.The room - cool products that you will enjoy using, glass bathroom with privacy shade, heated floors, rain shower, eco-friendly aspects, bottle of water waiting (great after a day of shopping in SOHO!), robes, slippers, natural fabric linens on the bed, reading lamps that don't keep your mate awake, ample closet space, and ample living space in the king studio.The David Burke Restaurant is set to open Feb. 1st of 2011 (as they told me), and I would like to try that out!Although it isn't in the middle of the stores in SOHO, I think that it is nice to have the space and the views that this building affords. There are even "zen" gardens - SPACE! Hard to get in a NYC hotel.This apparently opened in October of 2010, and I didn't see service of construction flaws - this is a good sign for such a brand new place!I look forward to seeing the great people in this hotel, and experiencing the warm welcome again.

My husband and I stayed here for 4 nights in January during a business trip. The location is excellent, you are in Soho and have everything on your doorstep. This is a great place for shopping, eating and art. I think that we had a standard guest room and with the large windows, gave a great feeling of space and airiness. I cannot fault the design of the room or the hotel. The bathroom is luxurious, the TVHD perfect and the bed AMAZING! I think that I would say that the bed was the best that I had slept in in New York. Very comfy organic sheets.The staff were unbelievable, someone has already said, they know your every whim before you do without being obtrusive or annoying. Housekeeping were so sweet, I was not feeling very well for most of the stay and when I returned to the room mid cleaning, my husband notified the lady that I was not feeling well and they said that they would clean up swiftly and the room would be ready in 10. I went down to the lobby and was politely informed by one of the managers that the room was now ready. Beautifully cleaned with a little note saying that they hoped that I would feel better soon. Complimentary tea or coffee was offered and served in the lobby or when you arrived.If you like a mid century modern touch to your hotel decor and wonderful service, choose the James.

We stood at the hotel for six nights and thought it was one of the best stays we had in NY - we now have two favorite hotels in the city: the modern, sophisticated James for downtown/Soho and the more classic Carlyle for uptown. The staff was exceptionally good with the goal of really catering to the guests and seeking solutions without excessive pampering that can be sometimes annoying. Rooms were reasonably sized and well designed. Our main concern was the restaurant which wasn't open but coffee and pastries were made available complimentary in the morning and fruits etc. in the afternoon. Great place. Highly recommended.

My husband and I stayed here recently; I was here for business and he was here for leisure. Due to flight problems we ended up staying a total of two weeks. While not without some glitches here and there, overall I would highly recommend this hotel and am definitely looking forward to staying here again.I'll start off with the minor issues. We had booked on their website and highlighted some room preferences which were not originally honored. Given that the hotel was not full, we were a bit surprised, but after asking, they upgraded our room. Now, the king room we were in seemed identical to our deluxe king upgrade, but apparently the difference is the higher floor/view. As for the rooms, we found them to be not particularly big but perfectly adequate and I'm a big fan of the organic amenities. I only wish we had individual amenities that we could take with us, but I figure they did it that way for environmental reasons. The walls seemed to be a bit on the thin side, as we were awoken by our neighbors arguing one night and could even hear when they coughed. We had to move rooms several times. Once was because there was no hot water (which the hotel should have realized before moving us since they had planned work being done in the area),but they ended up upgrading us for the inconvenience. Also in one of the moves they lost our travel locks, but very kindly reimbursed us to purchase new ones. I had noticed that some of the new rooms we moved into were not fully stocked at the bar, and thus they incorrectly charged us for using the items (two times). However, they had no issue taking off the charges. There was a bit of an issue checking out, as the person did not initially offer me an itemized bill, and when I requested a 2 part bill, he had trouble figuring that out. Long story short, while there were issues, they were handled in a satisfactory matter. The staff was wonderful-friendly, responsive, professional and unpretentious. Even the pedicab biker was super friendly! The lobby is beautiful and the free snacks and magazines/papers were a lovely touch. The coffee could definitely be better, but the rest of the snacks were very good. The rooftop bar is very cozy and we had a great bartender who talked to us all night and made some great drinks. The location is fantastic as it's close to tons of shopping and restaurants. Once they have the restaurant up and running it'll be close to perfect (I think a spa would make it perfect!). For the price, I think you get great value. Most luxury boutique hotels will charge more, so I hope they don't raise prices. I'm looking forward to revisiting the hotel!

We stayed at the James in mid-December and had a great stay. The hotel was spotless. It is only a few months old and it looks like it was just opened. We were greeted early in the morning with fantastic fresh coffee and pastries - no charge - and in the evening with wine and cheese. The staff at the front desk couldn't do enough to help us have a great stay. We were with friends celebrating a 40th birthday and they really went out of their way to make us feel welcome. Our rooms were extremely comfortable and fairly spacious by NY standards. We have stayed at plenty of boutique hotels in New York and you always expect a room barely big enough to fit a bed. Our room felt roomy with a very comfortable bed. They were still waiting to open their restaurant but there are plenty of nearby options so it wasn't a problem for us.The only reason that I would keep from rating it 5 star is because of frustration around the rooftop bar. We weren't honestly that interested in the bar other than the fact that everyone at the hotel kept saying that we needed to check it out. We were only there for a Fri and Sat night so we didn't have many chances to see it. Friday night we came back early (around midnight) to have a drink there only to find out that there was a private event at the bar. The next day we attempted to get up there once again. Everyone assured us that the bar was open - no private event - so we should grab a drink Sat night. We were directed to the proper elevator (near the hotel elevators) only to be stopped by the person shuttling people up and down to the bar. Instead of welcoming us into the elevator, he directed us outside the hotel to the line along the side of the building. I guess that we should have expected this, but assumed that, as hotel guests, we had some preferential treatment. There was never mention of crowds and lines. We thought that we would have access to the bar associated with our hotel. When we didn't we were frustrated and found the manager who we expected would have a sympathetic ear. He didn't. He was actually the only person at the hotel that wasn't the least bit sympathetic. We finally learned that the hotel had no real connection with the bar which explained a lot. Separate management. If we would have known that from the beginning we would have had our expectations set properly and not returned for a late-night drink.Again, besides this confusion the stay was great. Other than the manager (who really had to do nothing more than act like he understood our disappointment) the staff was brilliant. We love the location and the hotel couldn't have been more pleasant.

My husband and I decided to take a "mini-vacation" for one night in Manhattan. I chose The James due to its mostly positive reviews, location, price, design, and amenities. I soon found out that some of the amenities that they claimed to provide were unavailable, leaving us a bit disappointed and frustrated with our stay. There are many positive aspects of this hotel. The location is great-so close to the shopping in Soho, as well as many other neighborhoods within walking distance. The hotel is also near two subway lines. They staff at the hotel were friendly and tried to be helpful. The rooms are interesting-they have a residential feel that comes off as quite cold, however, the room grew on me due to its simplicity. The bed was comfortable and we had a nice view of the west side of the city and New Jersey, but not the Hudson itself. This was the claim the website made and this was why I paid extra money for the room. This was the first thing I was a bit annoyed about. We were moved to a higher floor, but this did not matter, as I do not not think that any rooms at the hotel actually have a view of the Hudson. The room was a bit noisy as well-we could hear the elevator going up and down all night. Before we headed out for dinner, I called the front desk to ask for a DVD player, as my husband and I brought DVD's with us so we could spend a relaxing evening in the room. I had called the hotel earlier in the week to ask if a DVD player would be available, to which they said it would be. That evening, I spoke to someone who said they were bringing up the DVD player, but thirty minutes later received a call stating that the hotel did not have any. We were quite upset and on our way out for dinner, we spoke to the manager. After explaining our situation and expressing our disappointment, the manager finally asked what he could do. We asked him what he could do to appease the situation, and while he initially seemed unsure about what to do, he then offered to give us the night for free. We were a bit surprised by this offer and appreciated his generosity. So, I'm not really sure how to sum up my experience at The James. Some of it was good, but some of it was not so good. I think the potential is there, but there are some flaws that they need to sort out in order to provide the amenities and experience that guests are expecting during their stay.

Well it seems Giuliani must have a sibling in the hotel business, forget the room mills in Midtown, this is my first time staying this far down south and I will never go back up to Chelsea or Midtown. The service here alone was terrific, yes they are still sorting a couple of minor things out, but that just goes to show how great the staff is, they might not always have the immediate answer, but they will go and find out and you will never find yourself wondering if they will ever get back with you.The hotel itself is beautiful, quiet yet central street that keeps you in the center of the action of SoHo while making you think you are blocks away. The rooms are a bit smaller as is the course for NYC, but not bad at all. I was more than graciously accommodated on every request, and this as a Diamond HHonors and SPG Platinum member who has become accustomed to thinking that not getting abused on a regular basis is good service (sad, but true).Stay here. You will not regret it.

Ok, let's get the sticking point straight away - the hotel is dog friendly. Yes, yes - we all see the chic sophisticated New Yorkers strolling around Tribeca and Soho with their dog bags or little Foo Foo on a spangly lead. Look good don't they? What about when they're in the room next door, at midnight scratching around or barking at 07.30 in their enthusiasm for the morning walk. This is before you think about the little Foo Foo that was in your room the night before leaving little Foo Foo sized packages. Grim. As a European this was a show stopper for me. Cue room move #1 - goodnight, Foo Foo.There were some other issues too - The air con was powered by what sounded like broken rocks rattling around in there. The two modes, hurricane or armageddon meant that getting to sleep (if you could get past little Foo Foo next door) was close to impossible without turning it off. New York in November might sound chilly - not a bit of it. Cue room move #2.Whilst I've got the whip out I'll carry on - The hotel's credit card clearing operation had issues authorising our credit card beyond a certain limit. You see they seem to use a factoring house which takes the risk above a certain level (I'm guessing $2000). So when you turn up to get card authorisation for say $2500 then the hotel is guaranteed to get the $2000 and the factoring house take the risk (for a fee, of course). Where this falls over is when you turn up at 11pm, bleary eyed after the flight and try to check in. The card authorisation fails, so you try another card. This also fails. You try a card from another bank, that fails too. You use your own mobile to call back to the UK bank who confirm they allowed it to go through without an issues. 30 mins has now passed and you're still stood at the front desk. Any offer to authorise 1 night and sort it in the morning? No. Sit down in the foyer and we'll come over when we've got the authorisation house? No. Tired and now a bit grumpy we eventually got it resolved and wandered to bed. We took a corner suite which whilst nicely designed was pretty small. Ok, it's New York I can live with that. Because the hotel is so new the room was pretty much covered in dust but why lots of hairs too? Hmm.There's no place to eat breakfast - You have this in your room, which is pretty small with a single low level coffee table. Not ideal - but the breakfast was well presented and hot. I understand the restaurant will be open Q1 next year - that's a good thing.4 coat hangers in the wardrobe? What's that all about? Asked for more twice before they arrived. Oh, asked for non feather pillows on the booking too, that wasn't done.Phew - got all the bad bits out of the way. There ARE good facets to this hotel. The location is outstanding. Right between Tribeca and Soho, it's great. The staff are accommodating and friendly and keen to help - Still feel they're all finding their feet slightly as the place is so new, but in the face of my grumpy protests about Foo Foo late at night, they were pleasant.The bar on the top floor is fantastic. In summer it will be *the* cool place to be. There's an open air pool there too which isn't widely advertised.For the morning after there's a gym. Small, but good facilities and a great view over the city.So there you have it - Would I recommend it, hesitantly yes. But I'd advise going mid - late 2011 when all the rough edges have been sorted, the restaurant is open and with the caveat that they've changed the air con. On the other hand, if you don't care about sleep and you want to be New York cool - it's the right place.

I came in for five nights to see a dear friend of mine run the New York Marathon, and from the moment that I drove up the experience was wonderful. The James Hotel in SoHo opened in September of 2010, and though they had only been open for two months, the hotel staff was very knowledgeable and helpful. I have been in new hotels and restaurants before that it takes months and months to get things flowing, but The James does not have that problem. The hotel is beautiful, each hallway decorated with the artwork of local artists, the staff in uniforms designed by Buckler who has a shop in SoHo, the minibar stocked with all natural and organic snacks, organic body products in the bathroom, and every evening during turn down service they leave the most delicious chocolates on the nightstand that were locally made, as well... I reserved the Deluxe King Guestroom which landed me on the 3rd Floor, knowing that there was a chance that I would be staring straight into apartments across the street, or looking directly at a brick wall. However, I actually had a view! I did end up closing the heavier curtains at night, due to the fact that the window is so large that the outside air was cooling the room substantially, and was perfectly comfortable in the room after doing so. The beds and sheets were so soft and warm that I slept like a dream...The rooftop bar, Jimmy, is truly a sight to behold. Beautiful and comfortable furnishings, with an amazing view of not only Uptown, but looking out over the entire New York and New Jersey skyline. The bartenders and wait staff are great, and the martini was perfect...Guest services is perfect. I wasn't watching where I was stepping, and took a spill (scraping my face on the way down) across the street from the hotel on my second to last night there, and the door men ran across the street to pick me up. Not only did they help me back to my hotel room, but knew my name, had a manager come by with a first aid kit to clean me up, brought ice to my room, remembered that I had theatre tickets the next night and thereby had a makeup artist come to my room without any hassle on my part to take care of anything. V, the day door man, brought me extra chocolates to my room with a Get Well card an hour before the makeup artist showed up that next afternoon, so that I wouldn't be hungry if I got the munchies while getting my face fixed for the theatre... I could go on and on about the wonderfulness of the coffee and buns in the morning, the peacefulness of the hotel's own garden area, how it is perfectly located, and how much I cannot wait to go back when their restaurant is open. However, I will end with saying that this hotel is a treasure. Not only am I going back, but I am making this my home hotel in Manhattan. I love it. Do yourself a favor and go. Quickly...

We really enjoyed our stay at this James, although I will always be certain to upgrade to a larger room. The hotel opened at the beginning of Autumn and everything is new, works, and it has an arty, organic feel. I just hope the furnishings remain in good shape through the years. The location is fantastic, as the James sits on the border of Soho and Tribeca, within walking distance of the Village. The staff is young, hip and accommodating. As long as the prices remain within reason, The James is an excellent choice for downtown Manhattan.

Travelled with spouse for 3 night stay in November. Late 40"s. Booked a queen on a travel site in September and based on other rooms/prices available, are confident the hotel was very good value for our money.Emailed the hotel prior to our stay to advise of early arrival and inquire as to storing luggage. Received immediate positive reply as well as being advised the restaurant was not yet open but they were available to assist in making reservations and that breakfast could be ordered to your room.Arrived at 9:00 a.m. and were able to check in immediately and were upgraded to corner king room on the 9th floor. It was our anniversary and champagne and chocolates were provided. Amazing view with floor to ceiling windows.Hotel is modern and minimalist in design. Having art displayed on each floor by a different local artist a nice touch.Rooms are lovely, clean and modern - a bit on the small side (but probably a good size for NYC). Wood floors, windows that open (loved this), all the amenities and unique bathrooms. Bar fridge, Dean & Deluca snacks, lovely organic toiletries, turn down service, chocolates, twice daily cleaning. The room was extremely quiet; we did not hear any noise when windows were closed. Only quibble is the hot water in the shower. We were on the 9th floor and perhaps this is common for NYC, but it seemed to take a very long time to get hot water in the shower.Delicious pastries and coffee available in the lobby in the morning, wine and cheese between 5 and 7 and cookies late evening was a wonderful touch and very much appreciated. I'm not sure if this will continue once the restaurant opens but certainly hope it does.Staff and service very friendly and helpful. We did not get the chance to have a drink in the rooftop bar so cannot comment on the atmosphere/ambience (although my guess is it skews to a younger crowd). A staff member was kind enough to take us up there on the morning of our departure for a look. Nice bar and outdoor pool. Views are terrific. The space is small and cozy - not a large bar.Soho location great. 2 subway stations a minute or two away and a hotel rickshaw. We would definitely stay here again.

The staff at this hotel made us feel as welcome as any hotel we have ever stayed in. And the last time we stayed in NYC we stayed at the Four Seasons. The location is right in SoHo and only a few stops from the subway, if you are interested. We were a little worried about the privacy in the bathroom but the screen makes the bathroom completely private just like if it was traditional wall.The hotel bar is on the roof and seems pretty cool. There was an event going on the night we went up so its hard to say what it's like on a "normal" night but it was pretty fun the night we were there.The WiFi is free and works great. There is free coffee and pastries in the lobby for breakfast, you don't get that at the Four Seasons. I would stay here again in a second and recommend it to anyone looking for a great hotel at a reasonable price in that part of town.

We stayed at The James for three days in the beginning of november and the Hotel is very nice, has a great location and friendly staff. The rooms are nicely laid out, not big but ok size and nice details. Great view from the room!On the minus side the service is not really up to speed, the staff is friendly, smiling and willing to help but sometimes fails to deliver. A few examples is they forgot to clean our room one day (it was fixed after we told them), the Concierge printed out a walking map to the Standard Grill from Google Maps that took us through really shady streets instead of trying to show us some nice streets. The Hotel also had problems providing a room at 2pm which was the check in time.However the overall experience is that this was a very nice hotel which I would not hesitate to return to. Especially in some months when everything is finished and the service is up to speed!I also want to mention that we addressed our issues to the manager who listened to our complaints and also compensated us for it in a good way.

We have stayed in several NY city hotels. The James was the cleanest and the most hospitable hotel that we have stayed at. The room was not big, but not small either and we had a great widow view. They had a wine reception that lasted for severl hours, not one hour. We went up to the roof top bar and had a great view of the city and listened to some great music.The hotel is situated blocks away from Soho and he east village. Thanks to all at the hotel for such a great stay.Candido and Robin

From the moment we checked-in, The James, sought to every detail. We were celebrating a special occasion, and not only was our room upgraded, but a bottle of champagne, truffles, and a welcome note were waiting in the room. And speaking of the room...it's filled with light, a wonderfully comfortable bed, and the temperature is just right (including the ability to open windows). The only downside is that with all the windows, there are limited outlets (we'll take the windows). The gym is very well equipped with fantastic views, and while we didn't have time to enjoy the roof top bar, next trip it will be a must. What stands out most, however, is the staff. They're service oriented, but also seem "real" and "genuine". If you're looking for relaxed SoHo comfort, The James, should be on your list.

We stayed at The James from 10/18 - 10/21 and it was wonderful. The hotel was brand new, they were working on putting up the sign over the door. The building was not complete, they were working on outside landscaping. Inside the restaurant was under construction, the roof top bar and pool were scheduled to open at the end of the week.The staff was wonderful, helpful, they truly want to exceed your expectations. Our room was a King bed city view. Very contemporary, lots of space for a NYC room, a glass wall separates the bedroom from the bathroom, there is an electric curtain that closes for privacy. The city view rooms look towards the Southern part of the island and New Jersey. The fitness room is on the 17th floor, state of the art equipment and the views are spectaular 180 degrees. This hotel is in a great location, within walking distance is Chinatown, Little Italy, Financial District, The Village, close to the MTA. This whotel will be a great addition to SOHO.

I have stayed in so many hotels in New York on business and pleasure and none of them come close to the excellence of this hotel. Since the hotel is brand new, the feeling is crisp and impeccably clean. The location in Soho is perfect to get to the village, Soho and everything else downtown. Colin, the General Manager was very visible on site and made everyone feel special. The staff was perfectly accommodating without being intrusive. They do the little things with such ease. My favorites were the cinammon raisin rolls with perfect coffee in the am, the wine and cheese from 5-7 and the rickshaw service at the front door - all complimentary. I was absolutely enchanted at every turn including the awesome deal we got with breakfast. Book fast because once this secret gets out, the rooms will be hard to come by.

the location is great but they are missing a few things at this new hotel there is NO dresser and 4 hangers in the closet i don't see how you could share the room with another person because there would literally be nowhere to put all your stuff if you turn off the AC and open the wonderful windows then it's very noisy for sleeping and the drapes are very heavy plus under the drapes are the few outlets bed is very comfy but huge king lumpy pillows and at a 5* hotel i expect down there is a glass wall with a shade you can raise up and down in the bathroom which is very pretty but if you aren't alone you will be using the toilet in full view of your spouse/friend. when you lower the wall shade then the bathroom is quite dark it's still a work in progress. staff very nice & helpful wish they had some rooms with 2 beds and a dresser it's good for SOLO travelers lots of restaurants and shopping in the area

so, this hotel, which promises so much off the reputaiton of its excellent chicago sibling, and its impressive website, is seriously disappointing, and not just for the $ they are charging, apparently open since september 1, my stay, commencing today, oct 24, sees the hotel have no F+B services whatsoever, no liquor license, and no idea how to deal with these difficulties. when i called down to order some wine, having previously arrnaged to meet a group of friends at the bar (which on arrival i was told had not yet opened), i was first placed on hold for about 5 minutes, then told the hotel could not sell alcohol , as it had no license. a list of nearby wine stores and directions was promised to be sent to my room, but 15 mins later, nothing arrived. i left to meet my friends at the standard, where i had been staying prior to oving downtown to check out the new james. when arrived back, i called to ask why there was no menu in my room, as i wanted to order dinner., well>> no food available either, the reponse was "we'll send a few take out menus up to your room, u can call them and maybe get delivery?" and they call this 5* !! oh, i forgot to mention having to navigate my way round the painting crew on my room level hallway, doing some finishing late on a sunday night. why open a hotel before its finished - and if you do , surely you owe it to let guests know?seriously disappointing, can;t wait to escape, and will never,ever, return.

The James is a very attractive property. Aesthetically, it is well designed and the location is excellent for visiting Tribeca and SOHO. The hotel offers some unexpected perks such as complimentary drinks and snacks in the lobby; however, it has some quirks that are unexpected and disappointing:- very few power outlets in the rooms. existing outlets are awkwardly placed making them very hard to use. unbelievable for new construction- an in-room coffee maker is provided but you must place it in the bathroom sink or on the floor near the curtains in order to plug it in- no desk / work area- no kitchen / restaurantI liked the James but wanted to like it more. It is fine if you get a good deal but it would be extremely disappointing if the room rates were above $300/$350 USD.

The staff at this hotel is incredible! Definitely made our stay so much more enjoyable. They made us feel so welcomed,we felt very taken care of! It's in a great neighborhood. I loved Balthazar, Barelo, Spurs Diner, French Bakery (forgot the name)..all right up the street , all less than a 5 minute walk...all recommended by the front desk. They offer the nicest soaps/lotions/shampoo/robes in the room and I loved that they have housekeeping visit twice a day. The furniture in the room is well appointed, very good use of the space. Huge windows that open a bit (something else we loved) to let in a cool breeze from outside. Great blackout curtains and the coziest bed! That mattress....I'd like to buy that mattress for our home! Honestly, we travel a lot and it's been a long time that we had such an enjoyable stay. I'm trying to think what I didn't like...I think I'd have to say I didn't like that the restaurant wasn't opened yet...considering how well everything else was run at this hotel, I can only imagine that it would be a great place to eat. We definitely will return to The James in Soho!

We spend a great weekend in this hotel. The building and the decoration has been made with taste. The location is perfect off to the the crowdy soho.The staff are very kind and they recommend cool places to going out, much better than the staff from the standard and the maritime. The rooms are perfect, large bed and big bathroom, free wifi, iron and coffe maker what'else!The plus is the free snacks and wine in the lobby, very cool after a long shopping day.Please don't change anything!

Great location and excellent value (for NYC). The staff were some of the nicest and most friendly people I have ever encountered in New York, or anywhere. This is a great addition to the hotel scene in New York and I will stay here every time I am back in Soho.

We just returned yesterday from a 3 night stay at The James. It is a beautiful hotel with a great staff. They were so accomodating and very helpful, welcoming you by name and making you feel very comfortable. The hotel is in a great location, with beautiful views of New York. The bed was fabulously comfortable and the bathrooom was spectacular.In-room coffee is available, or you can stop in at the lobby and get coffee and danish in the morning, and wine and cheese in the evening.The local art which decorates the hotel is a great touch, with every floor representing a different artist. The rooftop bar will be spectacular when it is completed and I look forward to coming back and enjoying it.I highly recommend this hotel to any traveler in NYC.

Some bad, some good. Let's start with the bad:The reservations team didn't do the hotel any favors. We called to make a reservation under the hotel's own promotional advertisement on its website. They were offering rooms at $349 a night with a complimentary breakfast as long as you booked by Nov. 1. Well, it took an hour long phone call to finally get the rate. They kept putting me on hold while they "tried to get the rate." Several times they claimed it wasn't possible to book, that there was a disclaimer that it was "subject to availability." There was no disclaimer. So basically they lied to me several times. When I finally asked to speak with another manager (I was already on the phone with one supposedly) they gave me the rate. The room was beautiful, but the floor and curtains were dirty. It appeared the room had been sitting since the construction was completed, and no one came in the room prior to our stay to tidy it up. The floor was dusty and there was dirt on the baseboards and curtains. The bathroom, however, was very clean.The doorman never showed up with our luggage. We waited 30 minutes and finally called down. He apologized and came right up. When he arrived, he had a cart to bring our luggage down. We informed him again that we were just checking in and not checking out. He made an excuse, apologized and ran down to get our luggage. Ten minutes later we had our luggage. This wouldn't have been a big deal, but we were very hungry, and wanted to grab a sweater before leaving the hotel. The extra wait threw our schedule off. The only other complaint I have is about the bed. The mattress was very comfortable, and the bed overall was very clean. But the comforter was not very heavy, and it was difficult to stay warm. It was october, and nights only dipped into the 50s, so I cant imagine what it would be like to have this in the middle of the winter.As for the good;The hotel is wonderfully located. We walked just about everywhere. The bathrooms were nice, and the rain shower is a nice touch.The staff (besides the reservations team) was very friendly, and willing to help. The hotel gave us a voucher for a free night's stay Jan-March because of the construction still ongoing at the hotel. It was a nice touch, though not sure I'd use it. All in all, a mixed bag. I might give this hotel another chance, but only if the prices were reasonable. Considering they are trying to get over $400 a night when the hotel isn't even completed, I doubt that will happen. We'll see.
user_name:
tcallquest
Washington DC, District of Columbia

review_body: I really enjoyed this hotel, the freshness of it beeing new. I found the staff very friendly and helpful - very eager to please and make my stay as good as possible. On the downside, the hotel wasn´t really finished yet. Neighter the bar or restaurant was open - but the staff made up for that by offering drinks and snacks in the lobby area during the day. They also offerd in-room breakfast, which I really enjoyed since breakfast is the most important meal for me in the day and I would hate to have to go chasing my food in the mornings...Otherwise I had a look around the gym, which was on the 17th floor and had an amazing view and was really well equipped for beeing a small hotel gym.The room itself was on the small size (but aren´t all NY hotel rooms small?) but perfect furnished with a lovely bed an huge windows to let me just lay in bed looking at the view.Overall, I enjoyed my stay and would love to go back to experience the hotel again when it´s all done and the bar and restaurant is open, and even try the pool on the rooftop - next year maybe...

Great location. Clean, modern decor. Will be great once they work through some of the new hotel kinks. For those traveling in Q4 2010, you might think again. They're still finishing some construction. Bar and restaurant were not yet open. Management seems to be smart about the situation, but the staff needs a little polishing. Arrived at 4:30 p.m. and was told my room wasn't ready due to their "very generous" check-out policy, and I couldn't get an estimate of when it would be available. When checking-out, there were a host of others at the desk with similar "new hotel" issues. That said, give them a few months, and I'm sure that things will be ironed out. On location alone, would stay here again.

a brand new hotel in a charming Soho neighborhood- we felt like we were in a European town. The rooms were chic and more spacious than your typical New York boutique hotel, and the staff were among the most helpful and friendliest that I have ever encountered in travels all over the world!

I usually stay away from brand new hotels as often there are many kinks to iron out before all systems are working. In this case I need not have worried. Not a hitch, a great room (on a corner overlooking Soho and South) and the best thing was the staff. At every touch point they got it right. Great attention to detail everywhere from the stylish staff uniforms botanical Bathroom amenities in pump action dispensers allows you to luxuriate with no mess and fiddling. The shopping in the area is ridiculous. Pack Plastic.We will be back.
This hotel is very well located ! Breakfast is nice...Bedroom are very quiet.
The hotel staff were very helpful and friendly. The James just opened on Sept 1 and we arrived on Sept 18 for 2 nights. It is a very nice cozy hotel! feel like home!

We enjoy the combination of biking in NYC and trying out new Manhattan hotels. The test for the hotels is not only can they provide everything a hotel should provide, but can they also accommodate our bikes with ease? The James NY had only been open a couple of weeks when we tried it for our ongoing experiment, and I’m happy to report they passed with flying colors. Most of you will only care about the hotel part, but it may speak volumes about how they would handle your car, or your luggage, or any other “out of the ordinary” needs you may run by them.There were never any fewer than two people at the entryway, and they were friendly and smiling when we pulled up. One greeter immediately took our bikes, and the other our luggage (which we had rigged up to our bikes with a tram attachment). A woman at the desk explained that the check-in lobby was up the stairs. An elevator leading up there was not yet in service, but these bellmen (in particular, “V”) had absolutely no issue bringing our bikes, trams, and luggage up there for check-in. Thank you!The place appeared to be spotless and shiny new, yet lush and comfortable.We arrived a little before noon, and check-in is not until 3:00, however they happily upgraded us to a corner king, which was available immediately. Nice! While we checked in, “Dan” shook my hand, explained about the services (fitness center, lounge area with coffee and Danish in the morning, snacks all day, and wine, fruit, and cheese in the evenings, all complimentary). The lobby has pretty views, lots of glass, comfortable seating, and is clean, clean, clean. I was already impressed, and I hadn’t even seen our room yet.Up to our room, a corner king, on the 9th floor. Extremely plush, airy & open, just knock-out gorgeous. The James is at the corner of Grand & Thompson, and most of the buildings in the immediate area are relatively low-rise, so our corner view on the 9th floor was spectacular. Our bellman (sorry, I did not catch his name) explained how everything worked --- air conditioning, heated bathroom floor, shower, shades, docking station, etc. Room seemed very large, the space is intelligently laid out. Extremely comfortable king bed, a table and chair for dining/laptop/reading, a cushioned bench against the wall (next to the table) which we used both for seating and for a luggage rack, a mini-bar w/ fridge (with room to put our own beverages), and an absolutely spectacular bathroom! Actual shelving to put all our stuff! Many towels! Eco-friendly (and wonderful smelling) Harmonic products. Great lighting! Space galore! Nice big shower with two shower heads. One bathroom wall is glass, which faces into the room, but there is a shade that can be lowered with the push of a button if you’re the shy type.Every time we entered or exited the hotel, we were greeted by name, with a smile. Having been born and raised in NYC, we don’t need directions, but the staff did not hesitate to offer, always with a smile. I had the sincere feeling that these people enjoy their work; it really shows. The James knows how to hire staff.This is a five star hotel, without the precious ego & attitude that unfortunately follow so many hotels. We will, without a doubt, return again and again.
user_name:
call_me_a_cab
New York City, New York

review_body: Just returned from a five night stay at The James. Yes, they've just opened and are ironing out some kinks, but overall we had a wonderful experience. The lobby staff are all extremely pleasant and helpful, going out of their way to call you by name and assist with directions, dinner recommendations, etc. The complimentary wine and snacks in the lobby is a nice touch as well. The location in the middle of SoHo is ideal, with a subway station right around the corner. The hotel is modern, clean, and pretty quiet for NYC. The only negatives we experienced were a quirky shower and a dreadfully slow-to-arrive elevator.Upon checkout, they offered us a free night's stay after the new year, as the bar and rooftop lounge will be up and running then. A very gracious send off. We will be back!

Having stayed at the James in Chicago, I was excited to see them open a hotel in New York. When we were there, it wasn't fully complete, but was still amazing. The staff was super courteous, our room was upgraded. I would definitely stay here again. The hotel was also perfect walking distance from anything in Soho and a hop to the subway.

Having stayed at the James in Chicago, I was very excited to know that they were opening an outpost in NYC. I booked a room for 2 nights, fully aware that they would have been opened 6 days when I checked in. Overall, my experience was great. Here are a few of the highlights. The location is awesome. It is right on the edge of SoHo so you can walk to everything but you aren't right in the middle of the hub bub that can be a weekend night downtown. The employees are gracious and courteous and if they don't have the answers to something, they will find out for you. Check in was a little confusing but I think it was a function of growing pains. The rooms are clean and while not super spacious, they are not small and they are very bright. It was a pleasure to have huge windows that overlooked the city and let some great light in to the room. Furnishings are minimalist but very comfortable. One word of caution though. Do not lie on the bed while wearing dark clothes. I think the hotel will quickly discover they have a serious lint problem with their linens. Bathroom was spacious and comfortable and I really like the amenities that they used. I am torn by the fact that they are full sized bottles that are anchored to the wall because I won't remember what they were when I get back but they were of excellent quality.Positives: Friendly Service, turn down service with Kee's Chocolates, filtered water by your bed, location, comfortNegatives: Slightly disorganized. Nothing in room that explains amenities offered by hotel including gym location, wifi information and local restaurant suggestions. Still under some construction.I would stay at the James NYC again in a heartbeat and am in fact staying there 2 weeks from now and I look forward to seeing the progress they have made.
